  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Ester M.
      Gustilo and Joeprim G. Gustilo, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Nhin Thi Tang,
      and Tang Oriental Supermarket, Inc., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-212
Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 4, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        George Hamlin Oâ€™Kelley, III, of Mt. Pleasant and William Lloyd
          Taylor, of Kiawah Island, for Appellants.
        Philip A. Middleton, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Nhin
  Thi Tang and Tang Oriental Supermarket, Inc. (collectively Tang) appeal the
  master-in-equityâ€™s order granting judgment for Ester and Joeprim Gustilo (the
  Gustilos).Â  We affirm[1].Â  
FACTS
On April 6, 2000, the Gustilos entered
  into a contract to purchase Tang Oriental Supermarket (the Supermarket) from
  Tang for $250,000.Â  The purchase and sale
  agreement stated in paragraph 8.4 titled â€œAmendmentâ€ that â€œThis agreement may
  be amended only by a written instrument executed by the party or parties to be
  bound thereby.â€Â  Subsequently,
  the Gustilos made a $40,000 down payment using Mrs. Gustiloâ€™s credit card.Â  The
  Gustilos paid Tang $25,000 toward the purchase price in March of 2000.Â  The
  Gustilos paid $15,000 more in April which was placed in an escrow account.Â  Mrs.
  Gustilo testified she and her husband mortgaged two pieces of property valued
  at $210,000 in total, one located in Berkeley County and one in Charleston County, to Tang as collateral.Â  The parties stipulated the Gustilos paid Tang
  $83,046.95 pursuant to the April 2000 contract.
Running the Supermarket proved unsuccessful, and the Gustilos fell
  behind in rent payments.Â  In January 2001, the Gustilos allegedly entered into
  a new contract with Tang pursuant to which Tang would extinguish the Gustilosâ€™
  outstanding mortgages if the Gustilos allowed Tang to repossess the Supermarket.Â 
  The Gustilos moved out of the Supermarket and returned the keys to Tang.Â  However,
  Tang later refused to release the Gustilosâ€™ collateral, and the Gustilosâ€™
  property in Berkeley County was foreclosed.Â  Tang negotiated with Tony Mallari
  (Mallari) to purchase the store, and once she repossessed the Supermarket, Tang
  planned to immediately sell it to Mallari.Â  However, the sale to Mallari fell
  through.Â  The Gustilos testified they never knew about the potential buyer Tang
  lined up until they returned possession of the Supermarket to her.
The
  Gustilos brought suit against Tang for breach of contract, breach of contract
  accompanied by a fraudulent act, fraud and deceit, slander of title,
  conversion, and equitable satisfaction of mortgage.Â  Tang answered and
  counterclaimed alleging breach of contract and mortgage foreclosure.Â  After
  dismissing most causes of action, the trial court found specific performance
  was due under an oral agreement because the Gustilos completely performed their
  part of the bargain and voluntarily turned possession of the Supermarket over
  to Tang.Â  The trial court further found Tangâ€™s inability to resell the premises
  to Mallari did not alter the terms of the new contract with the Gustilos.Â  Based
  on these conclusions, the trial court determined the Gustilos were entitled to
  an order directing the Register Mesne Conveyance (RMC) Office for the County of Charleston to mark as paid in full and satisfied the mortgage on the Charleston County property which the Gustilos still owned.Â  The trial court found in favor
  of the Gustilos for their breach of contract and equitable satisfaction of
  their mortgage.Â  However, the trial court found they failed to establish any
  monetary damage as a result of the breach.Â  The trial court denied Tangâ€™s claims
  for breach of contract and foreclosure of mortgage.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for specific performance is one in equity.Â  Campbell v. Carr, 361 S.C. 258, 262, 603 S.E.2d 625, 627 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Our
  scope of review of a case heard by a master who enters a final judgment is to
  determine facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence. Â See Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237,
  391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).Â  Thus, the appellate court may reverse a factual
  finding by the trial judge in such cases when the appellant persuades the
  appellate court that the trial judgeâ€™s finding is against the preponderance of
  the evidence.Â  Campbell, 361 S.C. at 263, 603 S.E.2d at 627.Â  Pursuant
  to Rule 220(b), SCACR, when an appellate court chooses to find facts in
  accordance with its own view of the evidence, the court must state distinctly
  its findings of fact and the reason for its decision.Â  Dearybury v.
    Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Error in Granting Directed
  Verdict

  A.Â 
    Partial performance of an oral agreement 

Tang
  argues the trial court erred in granting the Gustilosâ€™ motion for directed
  verdict based on the Statute of Frauds because the Gustilos failed to meet
  their burden of introducing clear and convincing evidence the oral agreement
  had been partly performed.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review.
It
  is unclear whether this issue was actually raised at the trial level because
  the record Tang provided on appeal does not include portions of the trial
  transcript where Tang allegedly moved for a directed verdict.Â  Ordinarily, no
  point will be considered which does not appear in the record on appeal.Â  See Rule 210(h), SCACR.Â  Further, the appellant has the burden of presenting a
  sufficient record to allow review.Â  See, e.g., Helms Realty, Inc. v.
    Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 339-40, 611 S.E.2d 485, 487-88 (2005); Bridwell
      v. Bridwell, 279 S.C. 111, 113, 302 S.E.2d 856, 858 (1983); State v.
        Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 608, 611 S.E.2d 283, 294 (Ct. App. 2005); Hundley
          ex rel. Hundley v. Rite Aid of S.C., Inc., 339 S.C. 285, 306-07, 529 S.E.2d
  45, 57 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Therefore, due to the inadequacy of the record
  presented, whether the trial court erred in deciding Tangâ€™s directed verdict
  motion is not preserved for our review.Â  However,
  even if we were to reach the merits, this issue is unavailing to Tang.
When
  reviewing a trial courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict, this court will reverse
  the ruling only when no evidence supports the ruling or the ruling is
  controlled by an error of law.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 569,
  633 S.E.2d 505, 512 (2006); McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367
  S.C. 559, 564, 626 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006).Â  On review, the appellate court must
  determine whether a verdict for the party opposing the motion would be
  reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his or her
  favor.Â  Ericson v. Jones St. Publishers, L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 463, 629
  S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).Â  
Under
  the Statute of Frauds, certain contracts must be reduced to writing in order to
  be enforced.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10 (2007). Â In pertinent part,
  section 32-3-10 (4) (2007) bars actions which:

  [C]harge
    any person upon any contract or sale of lands, tenements or hereditaments or
    any interest in or concerning them . . . . Unless the agreement upon which such
    action shall be brought or some memorandum or note thereof shall be in writing
    and signed by the party to be charged therewith or some person thereunto by him
    lawfully authorized.

However,
  South Carolina courts recognize several exceptions to the Statute of Frauds
  writing requirement, including partial or complete performance. See, e.g., Stackhouse v. Cook, 271 S.C. 518, 521, 248 S.E.2d 482, 483 (1978); Scurry
    v. Edwards, 232 S.C. 53, 60-61, 100 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1957); Settlemeyer
      v. McCluney, 359 S.C. 317, 320, 596 S.E.2d 514, 516 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Where
  sufficient partial performance has occurred, courts of equity can enforce
  specific performance of an oral agreement for a land sale purchase, despite the
  Statute of Frauds. Â Scurry, 232 S.C. at 60-61, 100 S.E.2d at 816; Gibson
    v. Hrysikos, 293 S.C. 8, 13, 358 S.E.2d 173, 175-76 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  To do
  so, â€œa court of equity must find: 1) clear evidence of an oral agreement; 2)
  the agreement had been partially executed; and 3) the party who requested
  performance had completed or was willing to complete his part of the oral
  agreement.â€ Â Settlemeyer, 359 S.C. 317, 320, 596 S.E.2d 514, 516 (citing Gibson, 293 S.C. at 13-14, 358 S.E.2d at 176).
In
  the present case, the trial court found the Gustilos credible in their
  testimony regarding the new contract which was entered into and consummated in early
  January 2001.Â  Specifically, the Gustilos testified Tang offered to satisfy
  their outstanding mortgages if the Gustilos would allow her to repossess the Supermarket.Â 
  The trial court stated, â€œThe Gustilos testimony is quite clear on this point.Â 
  I conclude there is sufficient evidence by virtue of the somewhat ceremonious
  way in which the Gustilos returned the key to Mrs. Tang in January of 2001.â€Â 
  Therefore, based on the Gustilosâ€™ testimony and actions, we find clear and
  convincing evidence proves a new contract existed between the parties, thereby
  satisfying the first prong of Settlemeyer.Â  359 S.C. at 320, 596 S.E.2d at
  516.Â  
Additionally,
  the Gustilos relinquished management and ownership of the Supermarket by
  returning the keys to Tang.Â  Such action amounts to partial execution of the
  new agreement between Tang and the Gustilos, thereby satisfying the second
  prong of Settlemeyer.Â  Id. Â Finally, the preponderance of the
  evidence indicates Tang, as the party who requested performance, was willing to
  comply with her obligations under the new agreement when she initially
  negotiated with the Gustilos to regain ownership of the Supermarket. Â Though
  negotiations with Mallari ultimately fell through, Tang initially was willing
  to satisfy the outstanding mortgages on the Gustilosâ€™ two properties.Â  Furthermore,
  the Gustilos had no knowledge of Tangâ€™s negotiations with Mallari.Â  Therefore,
  we find Tangâ€™s inclination enough to satisfy the third prong under Settlemeyer.Â  Id.Â  
We
  affirm the trial courtâ€™s order finding sufficient partial performance occurred
  between the parties because the Gustilos established the elements of Settlemeyer.Â 
  Based on the finding of partial performance, the trial court could enforce
  specific performance of the oral agreement for the resale of the Supermarket,
  despite the Statute of Frauds.Â  

  B.Â 
    Parol Evidence Rule

Tang
  contends the trial court erred in finding the parties amended their purchase
  and sale agreement by a subsequent oral agreement after admitting parol evidence.Â 
  Specifically, Tang argues the parol evidence rule bars any testimony contradicting
  the express, unambiguous terms of the written agreements between the parties.Â 
  We disagree.[2]Â  
â€œThe
  parol evidence rule prevents the introduction of extrinsic evidence of agreements
  or understandings contemporaneous with or prior to execution of a written
  instrument when the extrinsic evidence is to be used to contradict, vary, or
  explain the written instrument.â€ Â Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354
  S.C. 459, 471, 581 S.E.2d 496, 502-03 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Estate of
    Holden v. Holden, 343 S.C. 267, 539 S.E.2d 703 (2000) and Crafton v.
      Brown, 346 S.C. 347, 550 S.E.2d 904 (Ct. App. 2001)).Â  However, â€œ[it] is
  axiomatic that there exists a well established exception to the parol evidence
  rule which allows extrinsic evidence by the party attacking an instrument on
  the ground of fraud.â€ Â Redwend, 354 S.C. at 471, 581 S.E.2d at 503
  (citing Bradley v. Hullander, 272 S.C. 6, 249 S.E.2d 486 (1978) and Allen-Parker
    Co. v. Lollis, 257 S.C. 266, 185 S.E.2d 739 (1971)).Â  
In
  the present case, the trial court granted Tang a directed verdict on the
  Gustilosâ€™ claims for fraud and deceit and for breach of contract accompanied by
  fraudulent act.Â  Therefore, based on the trial court finding no fraud occurred
  between the parties, Tang contends certain parol evidence is inadmissible.Â  However,
  because the trial court found the parties entered into a new oral agreement,
  the trial court allowed parol evidence. See, e.g., Smith v. McClam,
  289 S.C. 452, 457, 346 S.E.2d 720, 724 (1986) (citing Midland Timber Co. v.
    Furman, 111 S.C. 287, 97 S.E. 831 (1919) and Williston On Contracts, 3rd
      Ed., Â§ 636) (â€œA well recognized exception is that parol evidence may be
  admitted to show a separate and independent agreement, which is not
  inconsistent with the terms of a contemporaneous or subsequent written
  agreement, if it can be inferred that the parties did not intend the written
  paper to be a complete integration of the agreement.â€); Natâ€™l Loan &
    Exch. Bank v. Tolbert, 129 S.C. 503, 512, 124 S.E. 772, 775 (1924) (internal
  citation omitted) (â€œ[T]he parol evidence does not in any way deny that the
  original agreement of the parties was that which the writing purports to
  express, but merely goes to show that the parties have exercised their right to
  change or abrogate the same, or to make a new and independent contract . . . . All
  distinct and separate transactions may therefore be established and availed of
  whenever they are themselves valid. Now, a transaction subsequent in time must
  always be a separate transaction.â€).Â  Based on the trial courtâ€™s finding Tang
  and the Gustilos entered into a new contract, admission of parol evidence was
  not in error.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit such
  testimony though it may contradict express terms of a prior written agreement
  between the parties.Â Â  

  C.Â 
    Part performance as an affirmative defense

Next, Tang argues
  the Gustilos should have been precluded from arguing part performance as an
  affirmative defense to her claims against them.Â  We disagree.Â  Â  
South Carolina case
  law requires parties to clearly and definitely plead certain affirmative
  defenses, including part performance.Â  See Rule 8(c), SCRCP, (â€œIn
  pleading to a preceding pleading, a party shall set forth affirmatively the
  defenses: . . . statute of frauds, . . . waiver, and any other matter
  constituting an avoidance or affirmative defense.â€); Hill v. Watford, 276
  S.C. 344, 345, 278 S.E.2d 347, 348 (1981) (â€œ[P]art
  performance was clearly and definitely pled, as our case law requires.â€); McMillan
    v. King, 193 S.C. 14, 23, 7 S.E.2d 521, 526 (1940) (â€œ[T]he claim of part
  performance thereof, should each be alleged at least with definiteness and
  clarity when the sufficiency of the complaint is tested by demurrer.â€).Â 
  However, our rules of civil procedure also require this court to construe all
  pleadings so as â€œto do substantial justice to all parties.â€Â  Rule 8(f), SCRCP; see also Loftis v. Eck, 288 S.C. 154, 156, 341 S.E.2d 641, 642 (Ct. App.
  1986) (â€œ[P]leadings in both law and equity should be liberally construed to do
  substantial justice.â€). 
In their complaint,
  the Gustilos allege the parties agreed Tang would take the Supermarket back and
  release the security and collateral the Gustilos pledged at the time they
  purchased the store.Â  The Gustilos further allege they allowed Tang, in
  reliance on the agreement and in the course of dealings between the parties, to
  retake possession of the Supermarket.Â  After honoring their duties under the
  new agreement, the Gustilos argue Tang refused to honor her responsibility
  under the agreement to release the Gustilosâ€™ realÂ  property and collateral.Â  In
  her answer to the Gustilosâ€™ complaint, Tang counterclaimed, alleging breach of
  contract and mortgage foreclosure.Â  In defense of these counterclaims, the
  Gustilos replied and realleged the facts set forth in their complaint.
Based on the above
  cited South Carolina jurisprudence, we liberally construe the Gustilosâ€™
  allegations and find they sufficiently pled part performance.Â  Specifically, the
  Gustilosâ€™ allegation stating: Â â€œThereafter, the [Gustilos] allowed Tang, in
  reliance on the agreement and course of dealing between the parites, to retake
  possession of the store,â€ is enough to amount to affirmatively raising part
  performance as a defense.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in
  allowing the Gustilos to raise this issue at trial over Tangâ€™s objection.Â  
II. Failure to Establish
  Monetary Damages
In
  her next assertion to our court, Tang argues the trial court erred in granting
  the Gustilos a judgment because they failed to establish any monetary damage as
  a result of the alleged breach of contract.Â  This issue is not preserved for
  our review.Â  
Tang
  failed to make a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, alerting the trial court
  to this issue.Â  Therefore, this issue was not raised to or ruled upon by the
  trial court.Â  If Tang did make a Rule
  59(e) motion to the trial court, it does not appear in the record on appeal,
  and this argument still fails because Tang, as appellant, has the burden of
  producing a complete record.Â  See, e.g., Helms Realty, 363 S.C. at
  339-40, 611 S.E.2d at 487-88; Bridwell, 279 S.C. at 113, 302 S.E.2d at
  858 (1983); Carlson, 363 S.C. at 608, 611 S.E.2d at 294; Hundley,
  339 S.C. at 306-07, 529 S.E.2d at 57.
â€œAn
  issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an
  issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€Â  In
    re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004).Â  â€œIt is well
  settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court
  cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial
  court.â€Â  Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598
  S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).
The
  purpose of a Rule 59(e) motion is to request for the trial judge to reconsider
  matters properly encompassed in a decision on the merits.Â  Collins Music
    Co., Inc. v. IGT, 353 S.C. 559, 562, 579 S.E.2d 524, 525 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Regarding
  Rule 59(e) motions, the South Carolina Supreme Court stated:Â  

  A party may wish to file such a motion when she believes the court has
    misunderstood, failed to fully consider, or perhaps failed to rule on an
    argument or issue, and the party wishes for the court to reconsider or rule on
    it. A party must file such a motion when an issue or argument has been
    raised, but not ruled on, in order to preserve it for appellate review. . . . South Carolina appellate courts do not recognize the â€œplain error rule,â€ under which a court
    in certain circumstances is allowed to consider and rectify an error not raised
    below by the party.Â Â  

Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 24, 602 S.E.2d 772, 780 (2004) (internal
  citations omitted).
Recently,
  in Pye v. Estate of Fox, the South Carolina Supreme Court identified two
  ways to preserve an issue for appeal as either: â€œa ruling by the trial [court]
  or a post-trial motion.â€Â  369 S.C. 555, 566, 633 S.E.2d 505, 511 (2006).Â  The Pye court held an issue was preserved for review when Pye raised such issue to the
  trial court in a summary judgment motion and later in a Rule 59(e) motion.Â  369
  S.C. at 565, 633 S.E.2d at 510.Â  Though the trial court never ruled on the
  issue the motions raised, the Pye court found the issue was preserved by
  stating, â€œ[A]n exception to this rule exists where an issue is raised but not ruled upon at a Rule 59(e) hearing.â€Â  Id.Â  In its holding
  the court noted lawyers cannot force trial courts to address an issue, but â€œa
  properly requested ruling under Rule 59 is sufficient without a specific
  judicial decision on the matter.â€Â  Id. at 566, 633 S.E.2d at 511.Â  Â Â Â 
In
  the case sub judice, Tang protests the trial courtâ€™s order
  granting a judgment to the Gustilos.Â  However, in order to properly preserve
  such an issue for appeal, Tang must raise the issue to the trial court through a
  Rule 59(e) motion, giving the court an opportunity to address problematic
  rulings and issue a final ruling.Â  See Pye, 369 S.C. at 565, 633
  S.E.2d at 510; Elam, 361 S.C. at 24, 602 S.E.2d at 780; Collins, 353
  S.C. at 562, 579 S.E.2d at 525.Â  Instead, Tang directly appealed the trial
  courtâ€™s order granting judgment for the Gustilos.Â  We find this issue is not
  preserved for our review because Tang never raised it at the trial level.Â  
This
  issue fails on the merits as well.Â  To recover for a breach of contract, the
  plaintiff must prove:Â  (1) a binding contract entered into by the parties; (2)
  a breach or unjustifiable failure to perform the contract; and (3) damage
  suffered by the plaintiff as a direct and proximate result of the breach. See Fuller v. Eastern Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 240 S.C. 75, 89, 124 S.E.2d
  602, 610 (1962) (â€œThis being an action for the breach of contract, the burden
  was upon the respondent to prove the contract, its breach, and the damages
  caused by such breach.).Â  In a breach of contract action, the measure of
  damages is the loss actually suffered by the plaintiff as a result of the
  breach.Â  Collins Holding Corp. v. Landrum, 360 S.C. 346, 350, 601 S.E.2d
  332, 333 (2004); Minter v. GOCT, Inc., 322 S.C. 525, 528, 473 S.E.2d 67,
  70 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œThe purpose of an award of damages for breach of contract
  is to put the plaintiff in as good a position as he would have been in if the
  contract had been performed.â€Â  Minter, 322 S.C. at 528, 473 S.E.2d at 70.
Tang
  argues the trial court erred in granting the Gustilos a judgment because they
  failed to establish monetary damages.Â  The trial court made such a
  finding and in its order by stating, â€œIt is further ordered that the Plaintiff
  has failed to establish any monetary damage as a result of contract.â€Â  However,
  we find the Gustilos incurred damages, though not completely monetary in
  nature, as result of Tangâ€™s breach.Â  Specifically, the Gustilos incurred
  damages in the form of previous mortgage debt and damaged credit.Â  Furthermore,
  in finding for the Gustilos on their breach of contract cause of action, the
  trial court ordered the â€œRegister Mesne Conveyance for the County of Charleston . . . to mark the mortgage of Joeprim G. Gustilo and Ester M Gustilo to
  Tang Oriental Supermarket . . . paid in full and satisfied.â€
Therefore,
  we find the trial court properly found the Gustilos met their burden of proof
  by establishing damage suffered as a direct and proximate result of the breach.Â 
  Furthermore, we find South Carolina jurisprudence does not restrict damages
  solely to out-of-pocket expenses incurred by the breach.Â  Though contract
  damages ordinary consist of out of pocket expenses incurred by the breach and
  the gain above costs that would have been realized had the breach not occurred,
  we believe damages can exist in several forms, including debt or damaged
  credit.Â  But cf. S.C. Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby
    Dev. Co., Inc., 303 S.C. 74, 77, 399 S.E.2d 8, 11 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œIn the normal case, the damage will consist of two distinct elements: (1) out-of-pocket costs
  actually incurred as a result of the contract; and (2) the gain above costs
  that would have been realized had the contract been performed.â€) (emphasis
  added).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the ruling of the trial court.Â  
III. Error in Evidence Admission
Tang
  argues the trial court erred in admitting evidence of alleged
  misrepresentations by Tang based on the merger clause in the agreement between
  the parties.Â  We find Tang abandoned this issue on appeal.[3]Â  
An
  issue is deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal if the argument
  is raised in a brief but not supported by authority.Â  In re Care and
    Treatment of McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 93, 551 S.E.2d 235, 239 (2001).Â  In her
  Appellantâ€™s Brief, Tang failed to cite any authority in support of her
  assertion the trial court erred in admitting certain misrepresentations into
  evidence.Â  Therefore, we find Tang abandoned this issue on appeal, and we
  decline to consider the argument.Â  
On
  the merits, this issue fails as well.Â  The merger clause in Tangâ€™s agreement
  with Gustilos expressed there were no â€œrepresentations made by either party
  relative to the subject matter hereof, which are not expressly set forth
  herein.â€Â  Tang contends the trial court erred in allowing Mrs. Gustilo to
  testify regarding Tangâ€™s representations of the Supermarketâ€™s monthly gross
  revenue, which is contrary to the express terms of their agreement.
Admission
  of evidence is largely within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l
    Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 510 (2005); Gamble
      v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp. of S.C., 323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441
  (1996); Hofer v. St. Clair, 298 S.C. 503, 513, 381 S.E.2d 736, 742
  (1989); Seabrook Island Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Berger, 365 S.C. 234, 242,
  616 S.E.2d 431, 435 (Ct. App. 2005); R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry
    Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 439, 540 S.E.2d 113, 121 (Ct. App. 2000).Â 
  Therefore, under our scope of review, we must determine whether the trial court
  abused its discretion.Â  Elledge v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five,
  352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002); R & G Constr., Inc. v.
    Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. at 439, 540 S.E.2d at 121.Â  The trial
  courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless it is based on an error
  of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support. Whaley v. CSX
    Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 456, 483, 609 S.E.2d 286, 300 (2005); Fields,
  363 S.C. at 25-26, 609 S.E.2d at 509.Â  â€œFor this Court to reverse a case based
  on the admission of evidence, both error and prejudice must be shown.â€ Seabrook Island Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, 365 S.C. at 242, 616 S.E.2d at
  435; Stevens v. Allen, 336 S.C. 439, 448, 520 S.E.2d 625, 629 (Ct. App. 1999)
  (citing Timmons v. S.C. Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d
  805 (1970)).
Assuming
  without deciding the trial courtâ€™s admission of the evidence was error, we
  affirm nevertheless because there was no resulting prejudice to Tang.Â  See Starkey v. Bell, 281 S.C. 308, 315-16, 315 S.E.2d 153, 157 (Ct. App.
  1984) (â€œThe admission of evidence is discretionary with the trial judge whose
  ruling will not be disturbed in the absence of an abuse thereof amounting to an
  error of law, and prejudice.â€).Â  In the case sub judice, the trial court
  found the Gustilos, as plaintiffs, successfully met their burden and proved
  Tang breached their second contract.Â  Based on its decision to grant judgment
  in favor of the Gustilos, the trial court ordered the RMC to extinguish certain
  mortgages.Â  The trial court did not use the gross income figure in its
  calculation of damages, as there were no monetary damages established.Â  Rather,
  Mrs. Gustiloâ€™s brief testimony recalled preliminary negotiations leading up to
  the first contract entered into by the parties.Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial
  courtâ€™s decision to allow such testimony into evidence because we fail to see
  how such testimony prejudiced Tang.Â  
IV. Equitable Satisfaction of
  the Mortgage
Finally,
  Tang argues the Gustilos were not entitled to equitable satisfaction of their
  mortgages because she did not sell the business to Mallari.Â  We find this issue
  was abandoned on appeal. 
An
  issue is deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal if the argument
  is raised in a brief but not supported by authority.Â  In re Care and
    Treatment of McCracken, 346 S.C. at 93, 551 S.E.2d at 239.Â  Tang failed to
  cite any authority in support of her assertion that the Gustilos were not
  entitled to equitable satisfaction of their mortgages.Â  Therefore, we find Tang
  abandoned this issue on appeal, and we decline to consider the argument.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

  objection and the courtâ€™s ruling regarding Mrs. Gustilosâ€™ testimony under the
  parol evidence rule appear on pages 69-72 and page 109 in the record on appeal.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

      Manigault, Appellant,
				v.

      Manigault, Respondent.

Jocelyn B. Cate, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-221
Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 11, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Veronica G. Small, of North Charleston, for Appellant.
				Gregory Forman, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Janice Manigault (Wife)
  appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of her motion to reconsider reopening her
  divorce action against Charles Howard Manigault (Husband). We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On August 27, 2002,
  Wife brought an action for divorce and equitable distribution from Husband on
  the basis of adultery, after twenty-seven years of marriage.Â  Husband retained
  counsel, and on November 15, 2002, filed an answer and counter-claim,
  requesting an equitable distribution of the marital assets.
At a pretrial
  hearing held August 30, 2005, the parties were instructed to enter into
  mediation prior to trial and trial date was set for January 5, 2006.Â  While
  Husbandâ€™s counsel attended the pretrial hearing, Husband was not present.Â  On
  December 12, 2005, Husbandâ€™s counsel filed an ex-parte motion and order to be
  relieved as Husbandâ€™s counsel.Â  Mediation took place December 29, 2005, seventeen
  days after Husbandâ€™s counselâ€™s motion to be relieved as counsel was granted.Â  Nevertheless,
  the parties reached an agreement during mediation.Â  This agreement was reduced
  to writing by the mediator in a letter, but not signed by either party.Â 
  Husband and Wife anticipated this letter would be published and approved by the
  family court at the final hearing.
Husband failed to
  appear at the final hearing, and did not request a continuance.Â  Wife informed
  the family court an agreement was reached at mediation, but did not inform the
  court the agreement was memorialized in a letter by the mediator.Â  Instead, the
  Wife went forward with the trial in Husbandâ€™s absence.
Husband was served
  by mail the final order and decree of divorce, and subsequently filed a notice
  of motion and motion pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP, to vacate the final order and
  decree.Â  A hearing on Husbandâ€™s motion was held June 12, 2006, and the record
  was left open to receive an affidavit from Husbandâ€™s original counsel.Â  On July
  28, 2006, the family court granted Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate and reopen the
  case, stating:

	After
  reviewing the file, the affidavits submitted and hearing argument of counsel,
  this court issues the following order:
	
		
			1.
			This court grants [Husbandâ€™s] motion to vacate the 
			final order and reopen the case.  The court does this because 
			although the court was informed at the January 5, 2006 [sic] final 
			hearing that the parties may have reached a mediated agreement, it 
			was not revealed that there was a December 29, 2005 [sic] letter 
			from the mediator, Kathleen Moraska Ferri memorializing the terms of the Agreement.Â  Had the court
  been informed of this, it would have briefly stayed the proceedings in an
  attempt to locate [Husband] and determine if the mediated agreement was in fact
  the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  It was further represented to the Court by [Wifeâ€™s]
  counsel that she in fact hoped that the mediated agreement would be placed on
  the record that day.
 
		
		
			2. 
			If the parties are willing to have the mediated 
			agreement become the final order of the court, they may set a 
			hearing to have that agreement approved.
 
		
		
			3.
			If either party is unwilling to have the mediated 
			agreement become the final order of the court, this matter shall be 
			set for an expedited pre-trial to set this matter for trial.
		
	

Wife
  filed a motion to reconsider the order to reopen and to allow the final order
  and decree of divorce to remain in full force and effect, alleging there was no
  legal basis for granting a new trial.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s motion to
  reconsider. 
DISCUSSION
Wife
  contends the family court erred by denying her motion to reconsider its grant
  of Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate the final order and reopen the case.Â  We
  disagree.
â€œWe
  will reverse the family courtâ€™s granting of a new trial only where the grant
  constituted an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.â€Â  Blejski
    v. Blejski, 325 S.C. 491, 497, 480 S.E.2d 462, 466 (Ct. App. 1997); Howard
      v. Roberson, ___ S.C. ___, 654 S.E.2d 877, 880 (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œâ€˜The grant
  or denial of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge
  and his discretion will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are
  wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by
  error of law.â€™â€) (quoting Chapman v. Upstate RV & Marine, 364 S.C.
  82, 88-89, 610 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Vinson v. Harley,
  324 S.C. 389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996))); Trivelas v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Transp., 357 S.C. 545, 553, 593 S.E.2d 504, 508 (Ct. App. 2004); Henson
      v. Intâ€™l Paper Co., 358 S.C. 133, 146, 594 S.E.2d 499, 506 (Ct. App. 2004)
  (Anderson, J., concurring in part and dissenting in part) (quoting Stevens
    v. Allen, 336 S.C. 439, 446, 520 S.E.2d 625, 628-629 (Ct. App. 1999)
  (citing Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 404, 477 S.E.2d 715, 722 (Ct.
  App. 1996))); State v. Taylor, 348 S.C. 152, 159, 558 S.E.2d 917, 920
  (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œIt is well settled that the grant or refusal of a new trial
  is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€) (citing State v.
    Simmons, 279 S.C. 165, 166, 303 S.E.2d 857, 858 (1983)).Â  See Kennedy
      v. Griffin, 358 S.C. 122, 127, 595 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œThe
  denial of a motion for a new trial is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion and
  will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€); Waring v.
    Johnson, 341 S.C. 248, 256, 533 S.E.2d 906, 910 (Ct. App. 2000).
â€œ[T]he
  exercise of that discretion must be in accord with sound legal principles and
  practice. . . . [V]erdicts found after regular and legal trial in a competent
  court ought not lightly be disturbed.â€Â  Harrington v. Nicholson, 182
  S.C. 38, 41, 188 S.E. 372, 373 (1936).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises when the
  trial court was controlled by an error of law or when the order is without
  evidentiary support.â€Â  Hillman v. Pinion, 347 S.C. 253, 255, 554 S.E.2d
  427, 429 (Ct. App. 2001); Miller v. Miller, 375 S.C. 443, 452, 652
  S.E.2d 754, 759 (Ct. App. 2007) (quoting Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C.
  70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003)).
In
  the instant case, the judge granted a new trial when she learned the partiesâ€™
  mediated agreement was reduced to writing by the mediator but not presented to
  the court at trial by Wifeâ€™s counsel in Husbandâ€™s absence.Â  The judge reasoned
  she would have briefly stayed the proceedings to contact Husband to gain his
  consent.Â  Given the judgeâ€™s delayed knowledge of the written mediation
  agreement, it was within the courtâ€™s discretion to grant a new trial.Â  We find
  no abuse of discretion in this situation.Â  Because the court did not abuse its
  discretion in granting a new trial, we elect not to address Husbandâ€™s arguments
  to ignore Wifeâ€™s July 28, 2006, and October 13, 2006, affidavits and his
  alleged lack of notice.
Accordingly,
  we
AFFIRM.
ANDERSON, SHORT
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

				Helen K. Roberson, Respondent,

				Doe, adults and Richard Roe,

				and interest in the parcels of land 
				described in the Complaint herein or 
				any part thereof, Defendants, 
				of whom Yvonne Capers is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-224
Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 11,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John J. Dodds, III, of Mt. Pleasant; for
  Appellant.
				Robert A. Kerr, and Brendan P.
  Langendorfer, 
				of Mt. Pleasant; for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Yvonne
  Capers appeals the Master-in-Equityâ€™s refusal
to grant her a
  new trial or relief from judgment relating to a service of process by
  publication, ensuing default judgment, and sale of heirs property.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
At the center of this action are three parcels of unimproved
  property (Property) located along Highway 17 North in Charleston County. Â Ernest Capers owned an undivided one-sixth interest in the Property. Â Ernest Capers
  died November 19, 1998. Â Appellant Yvonne Capers (Capers) is Ernest Capersâ€™
  widow and sole heir. Â Â Â 
On November 5, 2002, Respondent Helen Roberson (Roberson) filed an
  action seeking a judicial declaration that she was the fee simple title owner
  of the Property. Â Robersonâ€™s counsel at that time, Russell Brown (Brown), filed
  a Motion for Service by Publication supported by an Affidavit of Publication.Â 
  In the supporting affidavit, Brown swore neither he nor Roberson knew the
  address or residence of the Defendants, including the widow of Ernest Capers. Â The
  affidavit also stated the Defendantsâ€™ â€œplace of residenceâ€¦ cannot with
  reasonable diligence be ascertainedâ€ by Brown or Roberson. Â The affidavit
  further stated the nature of the declaratory action sought and the Defendants,
  including the widow of Ernest Capers, were proper and necessary parties to the
  action. Â The Clerk of Court for Charleston County granted an Order of
  Publication on November 5, 2002. Â A notice which included Yvonne Capersâ€™ name
  along with the names of other Defendants was printed in the Moultrie News three
  times during November 2002. Â 
On December 9, 2003, the circuit court found Capers had been
  properly served, failed to respond, and was therefore in default. Â The circuit
  court referred the action to the Master-in-Equity (Master). Â A hearing was held
  before the Master on August 30, 2004. Â Thereafter the Master issued a Judgment
  of Sale and Distribution clearing title to the Property and ordering the
  Property be sold. Â Capers did not know of the hearing and did not appear;
  however, a fellow Defendant, Arthur Milligan, Jr., was present and represented
  by counsel. Â Milligan submitted evidence regarding the fair market value of the
  Property. Â Â Â 
On January 9, 2006, Roberson purchased the Property. Â Near
  the end of September 2006, Robersonâ€™s attorney, Louis Moore (Moore), called
  Capersâ€™ residence. Â On
  September 28, 2006, Moore delivered a check for $34,037.73, representing Capersâ€™ share of the Propertyâ€™s net sale
  proceeds, to Capersâ€™ attorney. Â Six days later Capersâ€™ attorney returned the
  check to Moore and filed a motion pursuant to Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP, for new
  trial or relief from judgment on the ground Capers had never been lawfully
  served. Â The Master heard Capersâ€™ motion on November 21, 2006, and subsequently
  denied the motion. The Master also denied Capersâ€™ Rule 59(e) Motion to Alter or
  Amend Judgment. Â Capers appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The grant or denial of new trial motions and motions under Rule 60(b) lie within the sound discretion of the judge. Stevens v. Allen, 336 S.C.
  439, 446, 520 S.E.2d 625, 628-29 (Ct. App. 1999); Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17-18, 594 S.E.2d 478,
  482 (2004).Â  Our standard of review, therefore,
  is limited to determining whether there was an abuse of discretion.Â  Raby
    Constr., L.L.P., 358 S.C. at 18, 594 S.E.2d at 482.Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when there is an error of
  law or a factual conclusion which is without evidentiary support.â€ Gooding
    v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 252, 487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Capers
  appeals the Masterâ€™s refusal to grant her motion for a new trial or relief from
  judgment.Â  In her affidavit to the Master, Capers stated she and her late
  husband had resided in the same residence in Awendaw for the last thirty years.
  Â During that time, her telephone number and listing in the telephone directory
  under William E. Capers has not changed. Â Capers contends she was never served
  or properly notified of the reference hearing or sale of the Property.
An order for service by publication may be issued pursuant to Section 15-9-710 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 1999) when an affidavit, satisfactory
  to the issuing officer, is made stating that the defendant, a resident of the
  state, cannot, after the exercise of due diligence, be found, and that a cause
  of action exists against him. S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-710(3) (Supp. 1999).Â  
â€œGenerally,
  absent fraud or collusion, once the issuing officer is satisfied with the
  supporting affidavit, the decision to order service by publication is final
  unless the order of publication is premised upon a facially defective
  affidavit.â€ Brown v. Malloy, 345 S.C. 113, 118, 546 S.E.2d 195, 197 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Wachovia Bank of S.C. v. Player, 334 S.C. 200, 204, 512
  S.E.2d 129, 131 (Ct. App. 1999), revâ€™d on other grounds, 341 S.C. 424, 535
  S.E.2d 128 (2000); Yarbrough v. Collins, 293 S.C. 290, 292-93, 360
  S.E.2d 300, 301 (1987) (holding the Court of Appeals erroneously added the
  requirement that an affidavit for publication must set forth facts showing due
  diligence had been exercised and the court should not consider the sufficiency
  of the affidavit when there was no allegation the affidavit was obtained by
  fraud or collusion); Montgomery v. Mullins, 325 S.C. 500, 506, 480
  S.E.2d 467, 470 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œthe trial court was without authority to
  overrule the finding of the clerk of court that the Mullinses could not, â€˜after
  due diligence, be found in the County and State of their last known
  residenceâ€™â€); Miles v. Lee, 319 S.C. 271, 274, 460 S.E.2d 423, 425 (Ct.
  App. 1995) (holding the affidavit for publication was facially defective when
  it named Kenneth Wayne Lee as the defendant and person to be served although
  Robert Lewis Miles, Sr. was the actual defendant in the adoption/termination of
  parental rights proceeding)).
Capers
  argues the Affidavit of Publication is facially defective because her name does
  not appear in the affidavit. Â Although the affidavit does not mention Capers by
  name, it includes Capers as one of the Defendants:

	â€œâ€¦joined
  in this cause under the fictitious names of John Doe, adults, and Richard Roe,
  infants, insane persons, and incompetents, being fictitious names, designating
  as a class any person or legal entity who may be an heir, distributee [sic],
  legatee, devisee, widow, â€¦ofâ€¦ Ernest Capers, â€¦and all other persons or legal
  entities, known and unknown, owning, having and claiming any right, title and
  interest in the parcels of land.â€ 

Capers is also specifically
  listed in the caption of the affidavit. Â In Miles v. Lee, this court
  found an affidavit was facially defective[2] when â€œit purported to show due diligence in ascertaining the whereabouts of
  someone other than the person to be served.â€ 319 S.C. 271, 274, 460 S.E.2d 423,
  425 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  No such situation exists in the present case. Â Indeed,
  Robersonâ€™s counsel was able to locate addresses and mail a Notice of Hearing to
  twenty-two other Defendants. Â Capers has not presented any evidence[3] Roberson or her counsel attempted to intentionally exclude Capers from the
  proceedings. 
In
  her brief to this court, Capers also argues it is clear no effort was made to
  locate her. Â Capers cites the fact that the Complaint, Affidavit of
  Publication, and Order of Publication were all filed on the same day. Â This argument
  also fails.Â  Section 15-9-710 prescribes no timelines or routine to follow when
  filing for service by publication. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-710 (Supp. 1999).Â  â€œAll that this section requires is, that it be made to
  appear by affidavit to the satisfaction of the officer who directs the
  publication, that the defendant has property in the State, that he cannot be
  found therein after due diligence, and that a cause of action exists against
  him.â€ Yates v. Gridley, 16 S.C. 496, 499 (1882).Â  The statute does not
  specify the character of the facts and circumstances which must be stated in
  the affidavit or the quantity of evidence necessary to satisfy the officer
  ordering publication.Â  Yarbrough, 293 S.C. at 292, 360 S.E.2d at
  301 (1987) (citing Yates, 16 S.C. at 500).Â  The publication affidavit can suffice
  even if it contains only a conclusory statement that due diligence was
  exercised[4] and does not set forth facts showing due diligence had, in fact, been
  exercised, so long as the affidavit satisfies the issuing officer.Â  Yarbrough,
  293 S.C. at 292-93, 360 S.E.2d at 301.Â  
Accordingly,
  the order of the Master is 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Hopkins v. Brown is another South Carolina
  case in which the courts have dealt with the issue of whether affidavits in
  support of notice by publication were facially defective. 2006-UP-276 (Ct. App.
  filed June 8, 2006).Â  In that case, the Respondent filed an affidavit indicating
  she could not locate the Appellant, and a Sherriffâ€™s Office filed an affidavit
  indicating they attempted to serve the Appellant but were unable to do so.Â 
  This court found, â€œ[t]here is nothing facially defective about these documents
  nor is there any testimony in the record that would indicate the information
  contained therein was untrue.â€ Â  
[3] â€œThe movant in a Rule 60(b) motion has the burden of presenting evidence proving the facts essential to
  entitle her to relief.â€ BB&T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 552, 633
  S.E.2d 501, 503 (2006).Â  The burden of presenting evidence of fraud or
  collusion, for example, through the testimony of the clerk who ordered the
  publication, falls to the Appellant. Wachovia Bank of S.C. v. Player,
  341 S.C. 424, 429, 535 S.E.2d 128, 130, n.5 (2000).
[4] â€œWhen the record is silent, the court will presume
  that what should have been done was done.â€Â  Miles v. Lee, 319 S.C. at
  274, 460 S.E.2d at 425 (citing Fouche v. Royal Indemnity Co. of N.Y.,
  217 S.C. 147, 60 S.E.2d 73 (1950)). Â Â

FACTS

Berlinsky and his brother jointly owned
  property at 103 Ashley Avenue in Charleston, South Carolina.Â  Berlinsky sought
  financing from Palmetto Federal Savings
  Bank of South Carolina (Bank) in order to purchase his brotherâ€™s half interest
  in the property. Â On August
  7, 1996, Berlinsky met with Dana Grooms, a loan officer in the Bankâ€™s Meeting Street office, to discuss Berlinskyâ€™s mortgage needs and the types of loans the Bank
  offered.Â  Specifically, Berlinsky was interested in an $80,000 mortgage at a
  30-year fixed rate of nine percent.Â  During their meeting, Grooms informed
  Berlinsky other Bank employees would review his loan application.Â  When he left
  the August 7 meeting, Berlinsky believed he and the Bank were in the process of
  completing a loan application, but did not believe he had a commitment from the
  Bank for an $80,000 loan.Â  After the meeting, Berlinsky completed the loan application
  and began gathering necessary documentation for approval.Â  
Berlinsky and Grooms remained in contact through additional
  meetings and phone calls.Â  Berlinsky testified he believed the Bank had
  approved a loan at the desired nine percent rate based on his interactions with
  the Bank.Â  Â However, Grooms testified she only offered to refinance Berlinskyâ€™s
  first mortgage rather than loan him $80,000 secured by a second mortgage.Â Â Â  Believing
  the Bank had approved his loan, Berlinsky scheduled a closing date for
  September 13, 1996.Â  On September 11, 1996, Grooms informed Berlinsky the Bank
  had not approved his fixed-rate mortgage. Â Grooms and Emory Ware, Groomsâ€™
  direct supervisor, met with Berlinsky thereafter[2] and explained why his loan had not been approved.Â  At the meeting, they offered
  Berlinsky alternative financing and Berlinsky declined their offer.Â  
Berlinsky brought suit against the Bank for negligent
  misrepresentation, breach of contract, and breach of contract accompanied by a
  fraudulent act.Â  In his complaint, Berlinsky alleged he had to seek alternative
  financing with another lending institution at a higher percentage rate with a
  longer amortization and incurred closing costs of $3,100 as a result of the
  Bank failing to honor its loan commitment.Â  The Bank moved for summary judgment
  based on the Statute of Frauds.Â  The trial court held Berlinskyâ€™s claims were
  barred under Section 37-10-107 of the South Carolina Code (2002) and found
  there was no meeting of the minds between the parties. Â The trial court denied
  Berlinskyâ€™s motion for reconsideration as well as his alternative motion to
  alter or amend the judgment.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary
  judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of material fact and the
  moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Â Wilson v.
    Moseley, 327 S.C. 144, 146, 488 S.E.2d 862, 863 (1997). Â In ruling on a
  motion for summary judgment, the evidence and all inferences which can be
  reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the
  non-moving party. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Writing Requirement
  under Statute of Frauds
Berlinsky
  argues the trial court erred in granting the Bank summary judgment based on Section
  37-10-107 of the South Carolina Code (2002).Â  Berlinsky contends[3] what constitutes a â€œwritingâ€ is unclear under Section 37-10-107 because the
  statute does not set forth the elements such a writing must contain.Â 
  Furthermore, he maintains the record contains ample writings between the
  parties sufficiently setting forth the essential terms of the mortgage
  agreement.Â  We disagree.Â  
The
  Statute of Frauds prevents parties from maintaining legal or equitable actions
  â€œbased upon a failure to perform an alleged promise . . . . to lend or borrow
  moneyâ€ unless a writing evidences such a contract.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  37-10-107(1)(a) (2002).Â  In pertinent part, Section 37-10-107(1)(c) bars claims
  which involve:

  [A]
    principal amount in excess of fifty thousand dollars, unless the party seeking
    to maintain the action or defense has received a writing from the party to be
    charged containing the material terms and conditions of the promise,
    undertaking, accepted offer, commitment, or agreement and the party to be
    charged, or its duly authorized agent, has signed the writing.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§37-10-107(1)(c) (2002).Â  
Berlinskyâ€™s
  causes of action against the Bank included:Â  (1) breach of contract; (2)
  negligent misrepresentation; and (3) breach of contract accompanied by a
  fraudulent act.Â  We find all of Berlinskyâ€™s claims against the Bank are subject
  to the writing requirements set forth in Section 37-10-107(1) because he sought
  financing from the Bank for a loan in excess of $50,000.Â  Although Berlinsky
  contends the record contains ample writings between the parties setting forth
  the essential terms of the loan agreement, we find no such writing, evidencing
  the contract, exists.[4]Â 
  Berlinskyâ€™s loan application is the only writing in the Record on Appeal
  containing material terms of a mortgage agreement and signed by Grooms, the
  Bankâ€™s duly authorized agent.Â  Although it is signed by Grooms, we find this
  writing fails to satisfy the requirements of Section 37-10-107(1)(c) because it
  does not contain any indication of a promise, undertaking, accepted offer,
  commitment, or agreement between the parties. Â The loan application merely
  indicates Berlinskyâ€™s efforts in obtaining approval for a second mortgage.[5]Â  
Without
  any evidence to conclude otherwise, we find Section 37-10-107(1)(a), prohibiting
  legal or equitable relief based on â€œfailure to perform an alleged promise,â€
  bars Berlinskyâ€™s breach of contract claims.Â  Likewise, since Section
  37-10-107(2)(d) also contains a writing requirement, it bars Berlinskyâ€™s negligent
  misrepresentation claim.
II.Â  Real Estate Mortgage
  Exception
Alternatively,
  Berlinsky cites Section 37-10-107(3)(d) of the South Carolina Code (2002) and
  argues the â€œreal estate mortgage exceptionâ€ excludes his claim from the scope
  of the Statute of Frauds.Â  He contends his claims are not subject to the writing
  requirement because his transaction with the Bank concerned a second mortgage
  on an interest in real property which Section 37-10-107(3) excludes.Â  We
  disagree.
When
  courts are asked to define statutory terms, they must give the term its
  ordinary meaning.Â  Hernandez-Zuniga v. Tickle, 374 S.C. 235, 247, 647
  S.E.2d 691, 697 (Ct. App. 2007); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 102, 606
  S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œWhen faced with an undefined statutory term,
  the court must interpret the term in accord with its usual and customary
  meaning.â€). Â An ordinary and customary definition of â€œreal estate mortgageâ€ is
  a loan secured by an interest in real property.Â  See, e.g., Miller v.
    Eagle Star & British Dominions Ins. Co., of London, Eng., U.S. Branch, N.Y.,
  146 S.C. 123, 130-31, 143 S.E. 663, 666 (1928) (â€œA chattel mortgage is a
  conveyance of some present legal or equitable right in personal property, as
  security for the payment of money, or for the performance of some other act.â€); Johnson v. Johnson, 27 S.C. 309, 315, 3 S.E. 606, 609 (1887) (â€œ[A]ccording
  to the common law, a mortgage was a â€˜conveyance of an estate by way of pledge
  for the security of a debt, and to become void upon the payment of it.â€™â€);Â  See also Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 821
  (7th ed. 2000) (â€œA conveyance of title to property that is given as security
  for the payment of a debt or the performance of a duty and that will become
  void upon payment or performance according to the stipulated terms.â€). 
In
  the present case, we find Berlinskyâ€™s claims are not subject to the real estate
  mortgage exception for the simple reason no mortgage ever existed.Â  Berlinskyâ€™s
  suit arose from the Bankâ€™s failure to close a loan it allegedly committed to
  make.Â  Berlinskyâ€™s own assertions demonstrate the absence of such a
  commitment.Â  Furthermore, South Carolina jurisprudence provides â€œmerely
  preliminary negotiations between the parties . . . do not amount to an
  enforceable contract.â€Â  Electro Lab of Aiken, Inc. v. Sharp Constr. Co. of
    Sumter, Inc., 357 S.C. 363, 370, 593 S.E.2d 170, 174 (Ct. App. 2004); see also McLaurin v. Hamer, 165 S.C. 411, 420, 164 S.E. 2, 5 (1932) (stating
  there is no meeting of the minds between the parties when they are merely
  negotiating the terms of an agreement).Â  Seeking approval for a loan and
  entering into an enforceable mortgage agreement are clearly different; therefore,
  Berlinskyâ€™s claims are subject to the writing requirements set forth in Section
  37-10-107(1) and are not excluded by Section 37-10-107(3)(d).Â  Accordingly, the
  trial court did not err in dismissing Berlinskyâ€™s claims against the Bank.Â  
Because
  our determination on the Statute of Frauds issue is dispositive, we need not
  address whether the trial court erred in finding there was no meeting of the
  minds. Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598,
  613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review
  remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the
  appeal); Dwyer v. Tom Jenkins Realty, Inc., 289 S.C. 118, 120, 344
  S.E.2d 886, 888 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œWhere a decision is based on two grounds,
  either of which, independent of the other, is sufficient to support it, it will
  not be reversed on appeal because one of those grounds is erroneous.â€).
CONCLUSION
The
  trial court properly granted the Bankâ€™s motion for summary judgment based on
  the Statute of Frauds.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Berlinsky contends this meeting occurred on September
13, 1996, while Grooms believes the meeting happened on September 16, 1996.Â  
[3] Berlinsky makes this argument although he contends
Section 37-10-107 does not apply to his dealings with the Bank.
[4] In his brief, Berlinsky cites page 261 of the Record
  on Appeal in support of this argument.Â  Page 261 contains only an argument from
  Berlinskyâ€™s attorney explaining to the court he has â€œlots of writings back and
  forth containing all of the essential terms of what [Berlinsky] says was his
loan, which are in the record.â€ 
[5] Other writings between the parties include a:Â  (1)
  letter from Grooms to Berlinsky regarding the refinancing of his first real
  estate mortgage; (2) note and business card from Berlinsky to Grooms; (3)
  unsigned debt servicing worksheet; (4) unsigned loan decision worksheet; (5)
  unsigned loan worksheet; (6) letter from Berlinsky to the Bank regarding his
  â€œunpleasant experience;â€ (7) response letter from the Bank to Berlinsky; (8)
  letter from Grooms to Berlinskyâ€™s secured creditors; and (9) verification of
Berlinskyâ€™s first mortgage.
