  DISMISSED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Weston v. Margaret J. Weston Medical Center
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE
  STATE OF
  
      
  SOUTH CAROLINA
  In
  The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Paul Weston, MD, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Margaret
          
          J.
          
          Weston
          
          Medical
          
          Center, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Odessa K. Chavous, Third-Party Defendant,
      
    
  


Appeal From
  
    
  Aiken
  
CountyÂ 
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-240
  Heard February 12, 2008 â€“ Filed April 18,
  2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Charles J. Boykin and Karla McLawhorn Hawkins, both of
          Columbia,
          for Appellant.
        Donald Gist, DeAndrea Gist Benjamin,
          John S. Nichols, and Stephen Keith Benjamin, all of
          Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal stems from an action for breach of contract and breach of
  contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  The plaintiff, Dr. Paul Weston, M.D., (Weston) obtained a jury verdict
  for $200,000 in actual damages and $300,000 in punitive damages against the
  defendant, the
  
      
  Margaret
  
  J.
  
  Weston
  
  Medical
  
  Center
  (the Center).Â  The Center contends the
  trial judge erred in denying the Centerâ€™s: (1) motion for directed verdict; (2)
  motion for a new trial absolute; (3) motion for a new trial nisi remittitur;
  and (4) motion for a mistrial.Â  We
  affirm. 
FACTS
On June 24, 2002, Paul Weston, M.D.,
  (Weston) entered into a contract (the Contract) with the Center to serve as its
  medical director in

    
  Clearwater,
  
  South Carolina.Â  The Contract provided for a two-year term and
  an annual salary of $140,000.Â  The
  Contractâ€™s terms required Weston to work a forty-hour week or provide a minimum
  of eight hours per day in clinical services.Â  Additionally, the Contractâ€™s terms required Weston to attend to patients
  and render treatment, provide consultation with clinical personnel, nurses, and
  doctors, and participate in a quality assurance program.Â  The Contract contained a termination clause
  that provided the following: 

  This agreement shall be effective when all signatures have been affixed
    to the agreement and shall terminate 24 months after signing, however, this
    agreement shall be terminated by either party upon ninety (90) days written
    notice.Â  The [Center] may terminate the
    agreement without notice for cause and may terminate the agreement immediately
    in the event of financial exigency. 

The Center terminated Weston prior to the expiration of the contract for
  the stated reason of financial exigency.Â  David Macuch (Macuch),
  the Centerâ€™s chief financial officer (CFO), sent Weston a termination letter
  (the Letter) on August 7, 2003, which stated: 

  This letter is formal notice that your employment with [the Center] will
    terminate immediately due to financial exigency.Â  As you may recall, under paragraph ten (10)
    of your employment contract with the Center, the employment agreement may be
    terminated immediately in the event of financial exigency, or for cause.Â  As you know, the Center is currently
    undergoing a critical financial situation at the present time.Â  Because of this, and your unwillingness to
    adhere to the agreed upon job requirements provided in your employment
    agreement with the Center, which has added to the financial exigency, it has
    become necessary to sever the Centerâ€™s employment relationship with you
    immediately.
   . . . 
  I regret that this action is necessary, however,
    I am sure that you will agree that the continued success of [the Center] is
    what is most important to all of us.Â  Of
    course, should the Centerâ€™s financial situation improve, or the patient demand
    increase during the term of your contract, you will be invited to return to
    work.

Weston filed a complaint against the Center alleging retaliatory
  discharge, breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent
  act, gross negligence, and bad faith discharge.Â  The Center filed a third-party complaint against the former chief
  executive officer (CEO) of the Center, Odessa Chavous (Chavous), alleging breach
  of fiduciary duty. Â Chavous denied liability and filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial judge granted the motion for
  summary judgment and dismissed Chavous from the case.
  Â The case was tried before a jury in
  October 2005.Â  
At trial, Weston admitted he had no access to or knowledge of the
  Centerâ€™s financial status at the pertinent time.Â  However, Weston stated he believed the Board
  of Directors (the Board) â€œsimply used [him] to get their financial house in
  order.â€Â  In addition, Reverend Lester
  Smalls (Smalls), chairman of the Board when the Center hired Weston, testified
  regarding the Centerâ€™s financial situation.Â  As a member of the Board, he stated he received regular financial
  reports, and while he resigned in May 2003 prior to Westonâ€™s termination, he
  could not recall any financial strains while chairman.[1]Â  
Weston averred he performed his duties under the Contract and no one on
  the Board indicated to him they had problems with his job performance.[2] Weston admitted he saw a total of only 214 patients between July 2002 and July
  2003.Â  However, Weston testified he
  believed the Center had a deliberate plan to assign patients to other
  physicians to portray low productivity on Westonâ€™s part.Â  Weston stated the routing of patients
  began shortly after Chavousâ€™ hiring in August 2002. Â Weston further explained his patient numbers
  continued to decrease after Chavous transferred him
  in March 2003 to the Centerâ€™s new site in
  
      
  Jackson,
  
  South Carolina.Â  
Conversely, Weston claimed the Board did not carry out its duties under
  the Contract. Â The Board did not permit
  him to supervise other physicians or to participate in the quality assurance
  program.Â  Further, Weston stated there
  was no communication between his office and Chavous,
  who had taken charge of some of the other clinical employees. Â Weston opined this was done to â€œkeep [him] out
  of the loop.â€Â  Weston also stated he
  attended Board meetings in an attempt to give the medical directorâ€™s report and
  so he could report complaints regarding the way the Center was run. Â The complaints included the Boardâ€™s hiring
  of two unlicensed doctors and the limitation placed on Weston from carrying out
  the medical directorâ€™s supervisory duties.Â Â Â  
Weston stated he suffered damages in numerous ways.Â  According to Weston, the situation was
  emotional and traumatizing.Â  Also, Weston
  explained he built an â€œenviable recordâ€ and reputation in the fifty-five years
  of working in the medical community in
  
  Richmond
  
  County,
  
  Aiken
  
  County, the Edgefield area, and
  
  
  Augusta,
  Georgia
  .Â  Weston claimed his name had been vilified
  because of the Centerâ€™s breach.Â  Weston
  also stated he was due $140,000 under the contract. Â Additionally, to support Westonâ€™s alternative
  theory of modification of the Contract, he testified the Center never contacted
  him after the Letter to notify him he could return to work at the Center. 
Macuch testified he had serious concerns about
  the financial condition of the Center.Â  Specifically, Macuch testified that month
  after month, the Centerâ€™s expenses exceeded its revenues.Â  He explained the disparity existed because
  the revenue from patient encounters was not sufficient to support the growing
  number of personnel at the Center.Â  The
  Center also opened a new site in
  
      
  Jackson,
  
  South Carolina, in March
  2003.Â  Macuch stated it was expected the new center would operate at a loss for the first
  year and at a reduced schedule compared to the
  
      
  Clearwater site.Â Â  
Macuch explained he met with Chavous monthly to discuss the upcoming Board meeting and
  the Centerâ€™s failing finances.Â  Chavous gave Macuch a copy of the
  Contract during a meeting.Â  Macuch reviewed the Contract to determine if there were any
  provisions that could be used to terminate Westonâ€™s employment.Â  According to Macuch,
  he reviewed the Contract and pointed out to Chavous that considering the financial condition of the Center, the Contract with
  Weston could be terminated.Â  Macuch testified he became chief operating officer after
  the Board terminated Chavousâ€™ employment in July
  2003. Â Macuch testified he terminated Westonâ€™s employment at the direction of the Board
  Chair.Â  He further stated had he not
  fired Weston, there would have been a continued financial drain on the
  Center.Â  He explained Weston was paid
  approximately $85,000 from January 2003 to August 2003 but had generated only
  $11,000 in revenue.Â  
After Weston concluded his case-in-chief, he moved to abandon all causes
  of action except breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by a
  fraudulent act.Â  The Center moved for a
  directed verdict on both causes of action, which the trial judge denied.Â Â Â  
During the Centerâ€™s case-in-chief,
  witnesses testified as to the Centerâ€™s financial status.Â  Maxine Jefferson, a Board member, testified a
  number of employees were laid off due to the financial crisis.Â  John Shirley (Shirley), the certified public
  accountant who conducted an independent review of the Centerâ€™s financial
  situation in May 2003, stated the Center was â€œrunning out of cashâ€ and was
  headed for rapid disaster.Â  Shirley
  stated his review revealed the Center had to either increase revenue or cut
  expenses, or it had only two months of operation before it had to shut
  down.Â  However, he also testified he did
  not consider in his review the CEOâ€™s aggressive strategy for growth of the
  Center in late 2002 and early 2003. Â Shirley
  also indicated he did not know the Centerâ€™s grant writer had obtained a $600,000
  grant from the government during the same time period as Shirleyâ€™s audit.Â Â  
The Center also called Dr. James Coleman (Coleman), the Centerâ€™s new CEO,
  to testify about documents from the Center.Â  The Center presented a letter from Health and Human Services dated March
  4, 2005, regarding the Agencyâ€™s response to the Centerâ€™s financial crisis for
  the 2003 fiscal year.Â  Weston objected on
  the grounds of hearsay and relevance. Â The trial judge inquired, â€œ[W]hat is the
  relevance of something in March 4 of â€™05 and weâ€™re talking about [Westonâ€™s]
  termination in July of â€™03?â€Â  Coleman
  testified the letter was in response to the Centerâ€™s handling of the financial
  crisis.Â  Weston again objected on grounds
  of relevancy, and while the letter was admitted into evidence, the trial judge
  further stated he did not see the relevance of the 2005 letter to the 2003
  events in question.Â  The Center moved for
  a mistrial based on the trial judgeâ€™s comments, but the trial judge denied the
  motion and offered to give a curative instruction.Â Â Â  
At the close of evidence, the Center renewed its motion for directed
  verdict.Â  The trial judge denied the
  motion and included a curative charge regarding his comments.Â  The trial judge then charged the jury
  on breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act. Â After deliberations, the jury returned a
  general verdict against the Center for breach of contract and breach of
  contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, awarding Weston $200,000 in actual
  damages for breach of contract and $300,000 in punitive damages for breach of
  contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  The Center filed its post-trial motions requesting the trial judge to
  set aside the jury verdict and judgment and grant it judgment notwithstanding
  the verdict, in accordance with its motions for directed verdict made during
  the trial. Â In the alternative, the
  Center requested a new trial absolute and a new trial nisi remittitur.
  Â The trial judge denied the Centerâ€™s
  post-trial motions. Â This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Directed
  Verdict
The Center contends the trial judge erred in denying its
  motion for directed verdict because Weston failed to produce any evidence the
  Center breached the Contract or breached the purported modified Contract.Â  We disagree. 
â€œIn deciding whether to grant or deny a directed verdict
  motion, the trial court is concerned only with the existence or non-existence
  of evidence.â€Â  Sims
    v. Giles, 343 S.C. 708, 714, 541 S.E.2d 857, 861 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible to
  more than one reasonable inference, the case should be submitted to the
  jury.Â  Pond Place
    Partners, Inc. v.

    Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 15,
  567 S.E.2d 881, 888 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œWhen reviewing the denial of a motion for directed
  verdict . . . this [C]ourt must view the evidence and
  all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â 
      
      
      Id.Â  (internal citations
  omitted).Â  The trial court can only be
  reversed by this Court when there is no evidence to support the ruling below or
  when the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Swinton Creek Nursery v.
    
    Edisto Farm
    Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 477, 514 S.E.2d 126, 130 (1999).
A.Â Breach
  of Contract 
The
  Center claims there is no breach of contract because it is â€œunrefutedâ€
  the Center suffered from â€œfinancial exigencyâ€ or a financial crisis.Â  Under Paragraph 10 of the
  Contract, â€œ[the Center] may terminate the agreement without notice for cause
  and may terminate the agreement immediately in the event of financial
  exigency.â€ Â Accordingly, the
  Center contends Westonâ€™s employment was terminated pursuant to the financial
  exigency provision contained in the Contract.Â  Weston argues he presented sufficient evidence the Center did not suffer
  from financial exigency.Â  We agree with
  Weston.Â  
To prevail in a breach of contract action, the plaintiff
  bears the burden of establishing (1) the existence and terms of the contract,
  (2) the defendantâ€™s breach of one or more of the contractual terms, and (3) the
  damages resulting from the breach.Â  Fuller
    v. E. Fire & Cas. Ins. Co.,
    240 S.C. 75, 89, 124 S.E.2d 602, 610 (1962).
Initially,
  we note Weston established the first element as it is undisputed a contract of
  employment existed between Weston and the Center.Â  Further, Weston established the second
  element since it was reasonable to conclude the Center breached the terms of
  the Contract because Weston presented evidence that the Center did not suffer
  from financial exigency at the time of his termination.Â  
Weston
  testified he believed the Center fired him after he brought the Center out of
  financial difficulty.Â  Further, Smalls
  testified that during Westonâ€™s tenure, the Center sought to aggressively grow
  its budget and the Center was â€œreally moving.â€Â  Additionally, Smalls did not recall â€œany financial strainsâ€ while on the
  Board.Â  While Shirley indicated there was
  an â€œurgent financial situationâ€ at the Center, he also testified he did not
  specifically trace money coming into and out of the Centerâ€™s bank account and
  did not know the Center had obtained a $600,000 grant.Â  Likewise, Shirley admitted he did not
  consider the fact the CEO was trying to aggressively grow the Center during
  late 2002 and early 2003.Â  Coleman acknowledged
  in his prior deposition testimony that the Center had a positive financial
  condition. Â Lastly, the jury could have
  reasonably found Weston satisfied the third element because Weston testified he
  lost $140,000 in wages due to his termination.Â  
Viewing
  the evidence in a light most favorable to Weston, we find the breach of
  contract claim was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Consequently, we affirm the portion of the
  trial courtâ€™s order denying the Centerâ€™s motion for directed verdict on breach
  of the Contract.
B.Â Modification
  of Contract 
The
  Center argues Weston presented no evidence to support his alternative theory of
  recovery based on modification of the Contract.Â  We decline to address this issue.
â€œUnder
  the â€˜two-issueâ€™ rule, when the jury returns a general verdict involving two or
  more issues and its verdict is supported as to at least one issue, the verdict
  will not be reversed on appeal.â€Â  Todd v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 287 S.C. 190, 193, 336 S.E.2d 472, 473-74 (1985).Â  Moreover, this Court will find it unnecessary
  to address all the grounds appealed when one requires affirmance.Â  Dropkin v. Beachwalk Villas Condo. Assâ€™n,
    Inc., 373 S.C. 360, 365,
    644 S.E.2d 808, 811 (Ct. App. 2007). 
In
  the instant case, the trial court charged the jury on breach of contract and
  breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  The jury returned a general verdict finding
  the Center had breached the Contract with Weston.Â  As explained above, there is evidence in the
  record that would allow a reasonable jury to conclude the Center breached the
  original Contract with Weston.Â  Because
  the jury returned a general verdict, we must uphold the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  See Smoak v. Liebherr-Am., Inc., 281 S.C. 420, 423, 315
  S.E.2d 116, 118 (1984) (holding when a case is presented to a jury on
  negligence and breach of warranty causes of action, the appellate court need
  not address breach of warranty exceptions if it finds the verdict was supported
  by the evidence under negligence theory); Anderson v. West, 270 S.C.
  184, 188, 241 S.E.2d 551, 553 (1978) (holding when a case is submitted to the
  jury on two or more issues and a general verdict is returned, the verdict will
  be upheld if it is supported by at least one issue).
II.Â  New Trial Absolute
The Center next argues the trial court erred in denying its
  motion for a new trial absolute, claiming the juryâ€™s verdict was grossly
  excessive and motivated by an improper purpose.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.Â Â Â  
On appeal, the Center challenges the $200,000 actual
  damages award on the ground that it is six times the amount permitted under the
  ninety-day notice provision in the Contract.Â  This multiplier is based on the Centerâ€™s argument that Weston is only
  entitled to recover his salary equivalent to the ninety-day notice provision or
  approximately $35,000.[3] Â However, at trial, the Center never relied on
  the ninety-day notice provision as a ground for terminating Weston; rather, the
  Center argued its only basis for terminating Weston was the financial exigency
  provision within the Contract.Â  Because this
  argument was not raised to the trial court, we are constrained by issue
  preservation principles from considering it on appeal. Â 

      See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339
  S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that for an issue to be
  preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by
  the trial court).
III.Â  Thirteenth Juror Doctrine
The Center contends the trial court erred by not
  granting a new trial pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine as the evidence
  failed to establish a breach or modification of the Contract.Â  We disagree.
The trial court, sitting as the thirteenth juror, is charged with
  the duty of seeing that justice is done, and it has the authority to grant new
  trials when it is convinced that a new trial is necessitated on the basis of
  the facts in the case. Â Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 401, 321 S.E.2d 40,
  45 (1984). Â Traditionally, in
  
      
  South Carolina, trial
  courts have the authority to grant a new trial upon the courtâ€™s finding that
  justice has not prevailed. Â Todd v. Owen Indus.
    Prods., Inc., 315
  S.C. 34, 35, 431 S.E.2d 596, 597 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Similarly, the trial court may grant a new
  trial if the verdict is inconsistent with the evidence and reflects the juryâ€™s
  confusion. Â Johnson v. Parker, 279 S.C. 132, 135, 303 S.E.2d 95,
  97 (1983). 
A
  trial courtâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon the facts will not be
  disturbed unless its decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusion
  was controlled by an error of law. Â Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254-55, 387
  S.E.2d 265, 267 (1990). Â When an order pertaining
  to a new trial is before this Court, our review is limited to the consideration
  of whether evidence exists to support the trial courtâ€™s order.Â 
      
      
      Id. at 255, 387 S.E.2d at 267.Â  
We
  find Weston presented sufficient evidence at trial which would permit the jury
  to find the Center breached the original Contract.Â  Because the verdict was not inconsistent with
  the evidence, we find the trial judge properly denied the Centerâ€™s motion to
  grant a new trial pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  
Additionally,
  the Center argues the trial judge erred in denying a new trial under the thirteenth
  juror doctrine as the evidence failed to support a breach of the purported
  modified Contract.Â  We find it unnecessary
  to address this issue because as previously discussed, there is evidence in the
  record to support breach of the original Contract.Â  Consequently, the application of the
  two-issue rule mandates affirmance.Â  See Smoak,
  281 S.C. at 423, 315 S.E.2d at 118 (stating that while appellant raised
  additional exceptions relating to the issue of whether there was sufficient
  evidence of breach of warranty in the record to support the juryâ€™s verdict, it
  was unnecessary to address those issues, as even if the Court found error, the
  application of the â€œtwo issue ruleâ€ would require affirmance).
IV.Â  Punitive Damages
 The Center also contends the punitive damages award was
  erroneous because Weston failed to present clear and convincing evidence that
  the Center fraudulently breached the Contract.Â  We disagree.
The
  amount of damages, actual or punitive, remains largely within the discretion of
  the finder of fact, as reviewed by the trial court. Â Gamble v. Stevenson,
  305 S.C. 104, 111, 406 S.E.2d 350, 355 (1991). Â The trial court is vested with considerable
  discretion over the amount of a punitive damages award, and this Courtâ€™s review
  is limited to correcting errors of law. Â Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 305, 536 S.E.2d 408, 421 (Ct. App. 2000).
  Â Moreover, the appellate court
  must affirm the trial courtâ€™s punitive damages findings if any evidence
  reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s factual findings. Â 
      
      
      Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., Inc., 358 S.C. 298,
  314, 594 S.E.2d 867, 875 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Furthermore, in determining whether the
  evidence is sufficient to support an award of punitive damages, this Court will
  consider the evidence in the light most favorable to the prevailing party and
  will give the prevailing party the benefit of every inference that can reasonably
  be drawn on his or her behalf.Â  Cash v. Kim, 288 S.C. 292, 297, 342 S.E.2d 61, 64 (Ct. App. 1986).
Mere
  breach of a contract, even if willful or with a fraudulent purpose, is not sufficient to entitle a plaintiff to go to the jury on the issue of punitive
  damages. Â Floyd v.
    Country Squire Mobile Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 51, 53, 336 S.E.2d 502, 503
  (Ct. App. 1985). Â To recover
  punitive damages for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, the
  plaintiff must prove three elements: (1) a breach of contract; (2) a fraudulent
  intent in breaching the contract; and (3) a fraudulent act accompanying the
  breach.Â 
      
      
      Id. at 53-54, 336
  S.E.2d at 503-04.Â  
As
  previously discussed, evidence exists to support the first element, breach of
  contract.Â  The evidence was likewise
  sufficient to support the juryâ€™s finding on the second and third elements.Â  The jury could reasonably infer from the
  evidence that the Centerâ€™s reliance on the financial exigency clause in the
  Contract was arguably a pretext for terminating Weston such that the second
  element is fulfilled.Â  Macuchâ€™s testimony indicates the Center fraudulently
  intended to breach Westonâ€™s Contract.Â  Macuch testified that the Board Chair, Chavous, gave Macuch a copy of the confidential Contract, despite knowing it was improper for Macuch to review it.Â  Macuch specifically reviewed the Contract to
  determine if there were any provisions that could be used to terminate Westonâ€™s
  employment.Â  He further testified he
  terminated Westonâ€™s employment at the direction of Chavous,
  and if Macuch had failed to terminate Weston, Macuch would have been terminated.Â  
Further, the third element, a fraudulent act accompanying the breach, is
  supported by the Letter.Â  A â€œfraudulent
  actâ€ is broadly defined as any act characterized by dishonesty in fact or
  unfair dealing.Â  RoTec Servs., Inc., v. Encompass Servs., Inc., 359 S.C.
  467, 470, 597 S.E.2d 881, 883 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In the Centerâ€™s Letter to Weston, the Center based his termination on
  the current financial exigency as well as his â€œunwillingness to adhere to the
  agreed upon job requirements.â€Â  Based on
  the evidence presented, the jury did not believe the Center suffered from
  financial exigency.Â  Further, Macuch testified that in his opinion, Weston fulfilled his
  obligations under the contract.Â  This
  being so, it was logical for the jury to also find the Center dealt dishonestly
  with Weston by using the financial exigency clause as its basis for terminating
  him.Â  
Finding
  these elements were satisfied, we believe the juryâ€™s award of $300,000 in
  punitive damages was well within the range of permissible awards given the
  $200,000 actual damages verdict.Â  Compare Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co.,
  321 S.C. 1, 10, 466 S.E.2d 727, 732 (1996) (upholding a punitive damage award
  that was approximately twenty-eight times the amount of compensatory damages) and Pinckney v. Orkin Exterminating Co., 268 S.C.
  430, 431, 234 S.E.2d 654, 654 (1977) (upholding an award of $5,000 in compensatory
  damages and $4,000 in punitive damages) with Atkinson v. Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc., 361 S.C. 156, 171, 604
  S.E.2d 385, 393 (2004) (reversing an award of punitive damages in a fraudulent
  breach of contract action and finding the 1 to 127 ratio was well above the
  average compensatory-punitive damages ratio).Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Weston, as we must,
  the juryâ€™s punitive damages award is not so arbitrary
  or lacking in evidentiary support as to constitute an error of law.
V.Â  Mistrial
Lastly,
  the Center contends the trial judgeâ€™s comments on the relevancy of the Centerâ€™s
  evidence warranted a mistrial despite the judgeâ€™s proffer of a curative
  instruction.Â  We disagree and affirm the
  trial court pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following
  authorities:Â  Black v. Charleston
    & W.C. Ry. Co., 87 S.C. 241, 244-45, 69 S.E. 230, 231 (1910) (finding
  remarks of the court made during the trial in passing on evidence are not
  within the constitutional prohibition against charging juries as to matters of
  fact, unless made to impress on the jury the opinion of the trial court as to
  some vital fact); State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 400, 360 S.E.2d 706, 711
  (1987) (holding remarks made by a trial judge in ruling on the admissibility of
  evidence or ruling on other matters during the trial do not fall within the
  prohibition against judges charging juries on issues of fact); State v. Mishoe,
  198 S.C. 215, 222-23, 17 S.E.2d 142, 145 (1941) (stating that remarks made by the
  trial court in the course of trial need not be confined in such narrow limits
  as to prevent the trial court from stating its reasons for its rulings); see also Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 306, 486 S.E.2d 750, 758 (1997)
  (finding curative instruction was sufficient to cure any alleged error when
  complaining party failed to show prejudice as a result of trial judgeâ€™s
  statement). 
CONCLUSION
Therefore,
  the order of the trial judge is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  Smalls served
  as a member of the Board for roughly eighteen months.Â  He testified he did not attend Board meetings
  after January 2003, in part because of the â€œpower click [on the Board] that had

title: Reep v. Sonco Technology
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        David P. Reep, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Sonco
          Technology, Employer, and Cypress Insurance Company, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-241
  Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 18,
  2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Adrianne L. Turner, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        William P. Hatfield, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In
  this workersâ€™ compensation case, Sonco Technology and Cyprus Insurance Company (collectively
  â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal the circuit court order affirming the South Carolina Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commissionâ€™s finding that David Reep did not experience a change
  of condition for the better.Â  Appellants also argue the circuit court erred in holding
  Reep suffered from trigger finger as a result of the accident and trigger
  finger is compensable under Reepâ€™s claim.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Reep worked at Sonco Technology as a
  welder/machinist. Â His job involved cutting, fitting, fabricating, and tacking
  weld devices. Â The work required him to use both hands and often involved heavy
  lifting of metal plates, welding supplies, and torches. 
Reep
  left his job in November of 1999 because of chronic pain, swelling, and loss of
  stregnth in both of hands. Â Reepâ€™s physician, Dr. Rush, diagnosed Reep
  with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome and performed open carpal tunnel releases
  on Reepâ€™s hands. Â Reep slowly recovered from the surgeries and began suffering
  from trigger finger. Â Dr. Rush opined Reep sustained a 7.5 percent impairment
  to each hand.Â  
Reep filed
  a workersâ€™ compensation action against Appellants on October 16, 2000.Â  The
  latter denied Reepâ€™s claim, arguing his injuries were limited to his wrists.Â 
  After a hearing, the single commissioner awarded Reep permanent disability
  benefits and medical expenses.Â  
On November 9, 2004, Appellants filed a
  request to stop compensation payments.Â  Appellants argued Reep experienced a
  change of condition for the better.Â  They relied upon video surveillance taken
  of Reep using a chainsaw to cut a fallen tree.
A
  hearing was held before the single commissioner on March 17, 2005.Â  Reep
  testified he used the chainsaw to cut down a dead tree for safety reasons.Â  He
  stated that Dr. Rush encouraged him to remain active to avoid the loss of use
  of his hands.Â  Reep also requested additional medical treatment to correct his
  trigger finger.Â  Dr. Rush recommended A-1 pulley release surgery for the
  triggering.
 The
  single commissioner held evidence did not support a finding that Reep
  experienced a change of condition for the better.Â  The single commissioner also
  found the videotape surveillance did not convince him that Reep could return to
  work or work outside of his restrictions.Â  The single commissioner further held
  Reep was entitled to additional medical treatment as recommended by Dr. Rush.
Appellants appealed to the appellate panel. The appellate panel
  affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s findings.Â  It specifically found Reep was
  entitled to treatment for his trigger finger as related to his original injury. Â Â Â Â 
Appellants then sought judicial review in the circuit court.Â  The
  circuit court affirmed the order of the appellate panel on all issues.Â 
  Appellants appeal.

LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â  Change of Condition
  for the Better
Appellants first
  argue the circuit court erred in finding substantial evidence supported the
  appellate panelâ€™s finding that Reep did not experience a change of condition
  for the better and could not return to work or perform work outside of his medical restrictions.Â  We disagree. 
â€œThe Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act provides a mechanism for reopening an award if there has been
  a change in condition.â€ Â Clark v. Aiken County Government, 366 S.C.
  102, 108, 620 S.E.2d 99, 102 (Ct. App. 2005); see S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-90 (Supp. 2006). Â The purpose of this section is to enable the commission to
  change the amount of compensation, including diminishing compensation when
  circumstances indicate a change of condition for the better. Cromer v.
    Newberry Cotton Mills, 201 S.C. 349, 354-55, 23 S.E.2d 19, 21
  (1942). Â Â The determination of whether a claimant has experienced a change of
  condition is a question for the fact finder.Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW,
  353 S.C. 100, 576 S.E.2d 191 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  An appellate court will not
  disturb the findings of the workersâ€™ compensation commission if its findings
  are supported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole.Â  Lark v.
    Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).
Here, substantial
  evidence supports the commissionâ€™s finding that Reep did not experience a
  change of condition for the better. Â The only evidence Appellants submitted to support a change of
  condition was the videotape of Reep using a chainsaw and one report from a
  non-treating physician who viewed the videotape.Â  Reep testified he used the
  chainsaw, but the chainsaw was only six pounds and was not as difficult to
  maneuver as the machines he used as a welder/machinist.Â  In addition, Reep
  testified Dr. Rush encouraged him to keep his hands active to avoid the loss of
  use of his hands. Â Reep also stated he has trouble making a fist with his
  hands, buttoning his clothing, zipping a zipper, squeezing toothpaste, tying
  his shoes, and shaving.Â  Further, Dr. Rushâ€™s medical evaluations indicate Reep
  continues to suffer pain in his hands and fingers. 
II.Â  Trigger Finger
Appellants next argue the circuit court
  erred in finding Reep suffered from trigger finger as a result of the accident
  and trigger finger is compensable under Reepâ€™s claim.Â  Specifically, Appellants
  argue Reepâ€™s trigger finger is not causally related to the accident or Reepâ€™s carpal
  tunnel syndrome. Â 
We are bound, of course, to uphold the commissionâ€™s
  decision unless its factual determination is not supported by substantial
  evidence. Jones v.
    Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 417-18, 586 S.E.2d 111,
  113-14 (2003); S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-386(A)(6) (Supp. 2006) (â€œ[T]he court
  shall not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of
  evidence on the questions of fact.â€).
While Dr. Rush never specifically opined that Reepâ€™s
  trigger finger condition is causally related to the accident or Reepâ€™s carpal
  tunnel syndrome, Dr. Rush noted that Reep experienced triggering within a month
  after his second carpal tunnel release surgery.Â  He recommended surgery on Reepâ€™s
  affected fingers as the appropriate treatment. Â We therefore hold substantial
  evidence was presented upon which the commission could conclude Reep suffered from trigger finger as a result of the accident. 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY,
  A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Carlson v. Poston Packing Company, Inc.
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Daryl Carlson, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Poston Packing
          Company, Inc., Employer, and Capital City Insurance Company, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Thomas A. Russo, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-243
  Submitted March 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 23,
  2008

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
REMANDED


  
    
      
        Mary Cecelia Robinson and William L.
          Smith, II, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Grady L. Beard, of Columbia, for
          Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this workersâ€™ compensation case, Darryl Carlson sought benefits from his
  employer, Poston Packing Company, Inc., and its carrier (collectively, Poston)
  after he slipped and fell while loading crates of food into a freezer.Â  The
  Single Commissioner found Carlson suffered multiple injuries to his groin due
  to the accident, including an inguinal hernia diagnosed eight months after the
  fall, as well as a psychological injury.Â  The Single Commissioner further found
  Carlson had not yet reached maximum medical improvement (MMI).Â  An Appellate
  Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission)
  upheld the determination that Carlson suffered injuries to his groin, but
  specifically reversed the portions of the order finding Carlson had suffered an
  inguinal hernia and a psychological injury as a result of the accident and that
  he had not reached MMI.Â  The circuit court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s order, and
  Carlson appeals.Â  We affirm insofar as there is substantial evidence to support
  the Commissionâ€™s determination that Carlson has not established hisÂ  claim for
  a psychological injury. We reverse the Commissionâ€™s findings that Carlson has
  not established his claim for a hernia and that Carlson has reached MMI.Â 
  Finally, we remand this case to the circuit court for it to direct the
  Commission to make a new determination as to MMI in light of our holding.[1]
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes
  the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Commission.Â  West v. Alliance Capital, 368 S.C. 246, 628 S.E.2d 279 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Under the APA, an appellate court may reverse or modify the
  decision of the Commission if the Commissionâ€™s findings, inferences,
  conclusions, or decisions are affected by an error of law or are clearly
  erroneous in view of the substantial evidence in the whole record.Â  Id.; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d) & (e) (Supp. 2007).Â 
  Substantial evidence is evidence that, considering the record as a whole, would
  allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion reached by the Commission.Â  Rodney
    v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 466 S.E.2d 357 (1996).
 The
  Commission is the ultimate fact-finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is
  not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Brayboy v. Clark
    Heating Co., 306 S.C. 56, 409 S.E.2d 767 (1991); Ross v. Am. Red Cross,
  298 S.C. 490, 381 S.E.2d 728 (1989).Â  The final determination of witness
  credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the
  Commission.Â  Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366
  (1995).Â  We may not substitute our judgment for that of the Commission
  concerning the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007).Â  The possibility of drawing two
  inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not mean the agencyâ€™s
  conclusion is unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Ellis v. Spartan Mills,
  276 S.C. 216, 277 S.E.2d 590 (1981). 
1.Â  Consideration
  of medical report and denial of claim for psychological injury (Carlsonâ€™s
  Issues I & II).Â  We hold the
  Commission properly determined the Single Commissioner erred in excluding from
  evidence the medical report of Dr. Selman Watson.Â  We likewise hold the
  Commission did not err in relying on the report and using it as a basis to deny
  Carlsonâ€™s claim for a psychological injury.Â  
Carlsonâ€™s accident occurred on September 8, 2003.[2]Â  Poston sent Carlson to Dr. Watson on October 22, 2004 for a
  psychological evaluation because Carlson was claiming that he sustained a
  psychological injury as a result of his accident.Â  The Commission noted Poston
  stated in its Prehearing Brief that it had not received a copy of the report,
  but that it reserved the right to submit it at the hearing.Â  At the hearing,
  the Single Commissioner did not allow the report in after Carlson objected,
  stating it was not timely because if the report were allowed in, then he would
  have to allow additional time for the doctor to be deposed and it would
  â€œclutter up the system.â€Â  The Commission ruled it was improper for the Single
  Commissioner not to allow the report because Carlson was on notice that Poston
  was waiting for the report, Carlson was the participant in the evaluation and
  thus was clearly aware that a report would be forthcoming, and Poston had no
  control over when the doctor issued his report.Â  We find no abuse of discretion
  with the Commissionâ€™s determination that Carlson was on notice about the report
  prior to the hearing, as well as the Commissionâ€™s consideration of the report.
Likewise, the Commission did not err in then considering this
  report as a basis for denying Carlsonâ€™s claim for a psychological injury.Â  Although there is certainly evidence supporting
  Carlsonâ€™s claims, there is contrary evidence in the record that the Commission
  relied upon to support its decision to reverse the Single Commissionerâ€™s
  finding Carlson suffered a compensable psychological claim.Â  The Commission
  noted that Dr. Watson opined in his report of October 22, 2004 that although
  Carlson suffered from some anxiety, â€œit does not rise to a level that would
  warrant specialized professional attention or the need for medication.â€ Â Further,
  the Commission noted â€œDr. Watson opined that there was reason to suspect some
  exaggeration of the claimantâ€™s condition as tested by the PAI profile.â€Â  In
  addition, â€œDr. Watson opined the claimant suffered from a personality disorder
  that had developed over quite some time.â€Â  Because we have found no error in
  the Commissionâ€™s finding that the Single Commissioner should not have excluded
  the report, the Commission properly considered Dr. Watsonâ€™s opinions.Â 
  Accordingly, based on our limited scope of review, we hold there is substantial
  evidence to support the decision of the Commission.
2.Â  Denial of
  compensation for inguinal hernia (Carlsonâ€™s Issue III).Â  We hold the Commission
  erred in reversing the Single Commissionerâ€™s finding that Carlsonâ€™s inguinal
  hernia was caused by his work-related accident of September 8, 2003.Â  Our
  holding in this regard is made with a profound appreciation of our limited and
  highly-deferential scope of
  appellate review.Â  Yet the concept of â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ must have some
  meaning, and having carefully reviewed the record, we are convinced that the
  evidence points to the inescapable conclusion that Carlsonâ€™s inguinal hernia
  was caused by his work-related accident, as found by the Single Commissioner
  and the dissenting member of the Commission.Â  We base this decision, in part,
  on our determination that the Commission committed a legal error in its
  characterization of the evidence.Â  And, as noted, substantial evidence does not
  support the Commissionâ€™s decision in this regard.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5)(d) & (e) (Supp. 2007) (stating an appellate court may
  reverse the Commission when its decision is affected by an error of law or is
  clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence
  on the whole record).Â  
Carlsonâ€™s authorized treating physicians were Dr. Carolyn Becker
  Reynolds of McLeod Occupational Health Associates and Dr. E. Daniel Guyton of
  Florence Urological Associates.Â  Carlson was diagnosed with a hernia in May
  2004 and had surgery to alleviate it in September 2004.Â  The Single Commissioner, citing the testimony of the
  treating physicians, particularly Dr. Reynolds, concluded Carlsonâ€™s hernia was
  caused by his work-related accident.Â  The Single Commissioner noted there was a
  delay in the diagnosis of Carlsonâ€™s hernia due to the fact that he was not
  given the particular type of ultrasound that would diagnose this condition.Â  In
  addition, Carlson was unable to undergo the physical exam necessary to discover
  the hernia in the early stages of his injury.[3]Â 
  Dr. Reynolds testified that she was â€œgreater than
  ninety percent certain that this [hernia] was [incurred] as a result of his
  [Carlsonâ€™s] initial injury.â€Â  The Single Commissioner observed:

  She [Dr. Reynolds] further explained that the hernia
    was not discovered after the initial injury because the injury to his scrotum
    prevented digital examination of the inguinal area and masked the hernia
    symptoms, and that the previous ultrasounds had not examined peristaltic
    movement. . . .Â  Dr. Reynolds was . . . adamant in her opinion that the
    September 8, 2003 injury caused Mr. Carlsonâ€™s hernia.Â  

McLeod
  Occupational Health Associates had referred Carlson to Dr. E. Daniel Guyton of
  Florence Urological Associates for treatment of the separate injury to his
  scrotum.Â  Dr. Guyton diagnosed Carlson as having an injury to his left
  epididymis (spermatic cord) and gave him conservative treatment.Â  When Carlson
  continued to have pain, Dr. Guyton surgically removed Carlsonâ€™s left epididymis
  in September 2004.Â  Dr. Guyton stated Carlsonâ€™s work injury caused a hematoma
  to form in Carlsonâ€™s left epidydimis and when it resolved, it left scar tissue
  that caused some pain.Â  
The
  Single Commissioner noted there was no evidence in the record that Carlsonâ€™s
  hernia pre-existed his September 8, 2003 accident, and there was no evidence in
  the record of any cause other than this accident.Â  The Single Commissioner
  further found that Carlson was â€œnot at MMI.â€Â  
In a two-to-one decision, the Commission reversed the Single
  Commissionerâ€™s finding that Carlsonâ€™s inguinal hernia was a compensable injury
  caused by his work-related accident.Â  The Commission correctly stated that
  under section 42-9-40 of the South Carolina Code, a claimant has the burden of
  â€œdefinitelyâ€ proving the following:Â  

  (1)Â  That there was an injury resulting in hernia or rupture;
  (2)Â  That the hernia or rupture appeared suddenly;
  (3)Â  That it was accompanied by pain;
  (4)Â  That the hernia or rupture immediately followed an accident;
    and
  (5)Â  That the hernia or rupture did not exist prior to the
    accident for which compensation is claimed.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  42-9-40 (1985).Â  
In reversing the Single Commissioner, a majority of the Commission
  inexplicably stated Dr. Reynolds â€œwas unable to state to within a reasonable
  degree of medical certainty that the claimantâ€™s hernia in May of 2004, was the
  result of his work injury on September 8, 2003.â€Â  This purported finding simply
  finds no evidentiary support in the record.Â  This alleged uncertainty on
  Dr. Reynoldsâ€™ part is a mischaracterization of her testimony.Â  Dr. Reynolds
  expressly testified that she was â€œgreater than ninety percent certain that this
  [hernia] was [incurred] as a result of his [Carlsonâ€™s] initial injury.â€Â  She stated it had gone undiagnosed and was â€œthe
  missing piece of the puzzleâ€ as to what was causing Carlsonâ€™s continuing pain.Â  Â Â Â 
Although the Commission was free to disbelieve Dr. Reynoldâ€™s
  testimony, it did not specifically find that her testimony was lacking
  credibility or reject it as otherwise flawed.Â  Rather, the Commission asserted
  that she failed to state an opinion to within a reasonable degree of medical
  certainty.Â  We believe this mischaracterization of the testimony is legal error
  that affected the result in this case.Â  Cf. Seaboard Sys. R.R., Inc.
    v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 275, 349 S.E.2d 896 (Ct. App. 1986)
  (recognizing the general principles that the Public Service Commission as an
  agency was responsible for determining the credibility of witnesses and that it
  was not required to accept testimony even if it were uncontradicted, but
  holding these principles â€œare not applicable in the instant case because the
  Commission did not indicate anywhere in its order that it rejected the evidence
  presented by Seaboard as not credibleâ€; the appellate court concluded the
  Commissionâ€™s decision was not supported by substantial evidence). 
Moreover, the Commission based its finding, in large part, on the testimony
  of Dr. Guyton, who treated the injury to Carlsonâ€™s epididymis.Â  The Commission
  stated, â€œImportantly, Dr. Guyton testified . . . the claimant could have
  sustained another accident which led to his hernia condition.â€Â  Upon reviewing
  his testimony, we note Dr. Guyton acknowledged that he did not diagnose
  Carlsonâ€™s hernia, did not treat him for a hernia, and he did not know when
  Carlson sustained his hernia.Â  Dr. Guyton stated the hernia could have been
  caused by his work-related accident or it was â€œpossibleâ€ that Carlsonâ€™s hernia
  was incurred after Carlsonâ€™s 2003 accident.Â  Dr. Guyton explained that
  sometimes hernias â€œare more subtle and it takes somebody with more expertise in
  dealing with hernias to determine whether that is, you know, symptomatic or not
  [and] whether the pain you are having is a hernia or not.â€Â  When asked about when Carlsonâ€™s hernia developed, Dr.
  Guyton stated that he would â€œhave to defer to general surgery [sic] who does
  hernia.â€ More to the point, Dr. Guyton made it crystal clear that
  his treatment of Carlson was unrelated to the hernia, for Dr. Guyton does not
  specifically treat hernias in his practice.Â  
We do not fault the Commission for assigning weight to the
  testimony of Dr. Guyton in its quest to deny compensability for Carlsonâ€™s
  hernia.Â  Our concern is with the complete lack of a nexus from the Commissionâ€™s
  findings and the actual evidence.Â  To be sure, the Commission is free to make
  findings, but those findings must have at least a slight connection to the
  evidentiary record.Â  Findings made from whole cloth cannot meet the minimal
  substantial evidence threshold.Â  Moreover, we are mindful that Dr. Guyton, when
  pressed, speculated that it was â€œpossibleâ€ that Carlson may have sustained
  another injury.Â  If such speculative testimony were found to be sufficient, the
  already thin concept of substantial evidence would be an empty shell.Â  Here,
  the only evidence to within a reasonable degree of medical certainty is that of
  Dr. Reynolds, whose testimony the Commission mischaracterized.Â  Because the
  only basis for the Commissionâ€™s decision rests on speculation, and
  concomitantly the evidence allows reasonable minds to only reach the conclusion
  that Carlsonâ€™s hernia was caused by the work related accident, we reverse the
  Commission.[4] 
Accordingly, based on the foregoing, we hold the Commission
  erred.Â  See Grant v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 202, 641
  S.E.2d 869, 872 (2007) (â€œWhile the appellate courts are required to be
  deferential to the full commission regarding questions of fact, this deference
  does not prevent the courts from overturning the full commissionâ€™s decision
  when it is legally incorrect as it is here.â€); Thompson v. S.C. Steel Erectors, 369 S.C. 606, 612, 632 S.E.2d 874, 878 (Ct.
  App. 2006) (stating under the APA an appellate court may reverse the
  Commissionâ€™s decision if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced
  because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record).
3.Â  Finding that
  MMI was reached by May 2004 (Carlsonâ€™s Issue IV).Â  Carlson lastly challenges
  the Commissionâ€™s determination that he reached MMI by May 2004.Â  The Commission
  concluded Carlson reached MMI after finding Carlsonâ€™s hematoma had resolved
  itself by May 2004 and that Carlsonâ€™s causally-related injuries did not include
  a hernia.Â  Since the Commission affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s finding that
  Carlson had also suffered an injury to his epididymis, and Carlsonâ€™s treatment
  for this injury occurred after May 2004, the Commission erred in finding
  Carlson had reached MMI by May 2004.Â  In addition, since we are reversing the
  finding regarding Carlsonâ€™s inguinal hernia and hold that it is compensable,
  the finding of MMI must be revisited.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the Commissionâ€™s
  finding in this regard and remand this matter to the circuit court, which shall
  direct the Commission to reconsider the issue of MMI.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Documents in the record on appeal also give the date
  of the accident as September 9, 2003.
[3] Dr. Reynolds testified that there were â€œbasically two
  reasons why the hernia was not diagnosed after [Carlsonâ€™s] September 2003
  incident.Â  One is that the concentration was on the scrotal and the testicular
  injury and the other would be that the ultrasound was not performed in a way
  that the hernia would be revealed[.]â€Â  Dr. Reynolds further stated Carlson
  could not be given a proper physical exam to detect the hernia in the earlier
  stages of his injury.Â  There is no evidence to contradict these findings.
[4]Â  Essentially, the Commission
  committed legal error in stating Dr. Reynolds failed to testify to within a
  reasonable degree of medical certainty about causation, even though she stated
  she was â€œgreater than ninety percent certainâ€ that the work-related accident
  caused Carlsonâ€™s hernia.Â  We believe Dr. Reynoldsâ€™s testimony meets the level
  of certainty required for medical causation.Â  Further, the Commission
  extensively relied upon the testimony of Dr. Guyton, even though he was unable
  to testify to a reasonable medical certainty about the cause of Carlsonâ€™s
  hernia and in fact stated he could not ascertain the cause of Carlsonâ€™s hernia
  because he did not treat him for that condition and would have to defer to the
  expertise of others.

title: Magaha v. Greenwood Mills, Inc.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Bessie M.
          Magaha, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Greenwood
          Mills, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
  Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-244
  Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 24,
  2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Roy R. Hemphill, of Greenwood; for Appellant.
        Carole Marie Dennison, of Greenville; John S. Nichols, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Greenwood Mills, Inc. (the Mill) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order in this
  workersâ€™ compensation action.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
Bessie M. Magaha was employed with the Mill for over thirty years
  as a weaver.Â  In November of 1998, the Mill transferred Magaha to work on a larger
  loom.Â  Magaha alleged she sustained an injury to her right shoulder, arm, and
  hand.Â  She first sought treatment for the pain from her family doctor on
  January 11, 1999.Â  Magaha had two surgeries on her shoulder and sought payment
  of medical expenses and temporary total and permanent total disability.Â  The
  Mill denied Magaha sustained an injury by accident and alleges it did not
  receive notice of the injury until it received a Form 50 on December 29, 2000,
  almost two years after the alleged accident.
At the hearing before the single commissioner, Magaha argued she
  suffered repetitive trauma to her right shoulder after moving to the larger
  loom.Â  Magaha is five-feet, one-inch tall, was in her sixties at the time of
  the alleged accident, and has a seventh grade education.Â  Magaha testified she
  informed Ronnie Butler, her supervisor at the Mill, of problems with her
  shoulder on the first day she used the new loom.Â  At a prior deposition, Magaha
  testified she told Butler the soreness in her shoulder and arm was getting
  worse but did not explicitly tell Butler the soreness was related to her work.Â 
  She explained at the hearing that she â€œfigured he probably would [think] . . .
  that itâ€™s something . . . from work.â€Â  Butler testified before the single
  commissioner that he did not remember whether Magaha told him about her injury.Â 
  Nor did he remember whether Magaha complained about the new loom.Â  Butler claimed he would have noted any complaints on Magahaâ€™s attendance card, pursuant to
  the Millâ€™s policy.Â  Butler conceded Magaha was a good worker, retired without
  any warnings, and rarely, if ever, complained.Â  
Magaha began receiving short-term disability benefits in March or
  April of 1999.Â  On her application for short term disability, Magaha
  represented that her injuries were not work-related.Â  On cross-examination on
  the issue, Magaha testified that the Mill did not explain the short-term
  disability form to her and she did not remember checking a box on the form
  denying her injury was work-related.Â  Magaha has suffered a stroke, has had a
  guardian ad litem appointed for her, and could not remember whether the Mill
  helped her fill out the disability forms.Â  Â Â 
After shoulder surgery in March of 1999, Magaha returned to work.Â 
  Within two weeks, the pain returned.Â  Magaha retired in July of 2000, had
  carpal tunnel surgery in October of 2000, and had a second shoulder surgery in
  February of 2002.Â  
Dr. Michael Bryant, Magahaâ€™s treating physician, wrote the Mill
  after Magahaâ€™s first consultation.Â  By letter dated January 19, 1999, Dr.
  Bryant informed the Mill:

  Ms. Magaha had been seen in my office on 1/11/99 with impingement
    syndrome with continued pain and discomfort.Â  She had some decreased strength
    secondary to the pain as well as pain on internal and external rotation of the
    right upper extremity . . . .Â  She is no longer doing the job that caused
      the impingement syndrome but continues to be debilitated at work working in
    pain. . . . I would appreciate your consideration in helping her cover this
    expense, as I think it will be less costly overall in her treatment. (Emphasis
    added.) 

The Mill
  stipulated it received this letter. Â Â 
The single commissioner found Magaha failed to prove a compensable
  injury and failed to give sufficient notice of having sustained an injury by
  accident.Â  With one dissent, the full commission adopted the findings of the
  single commissioner. 
Magaha
  appealed the issues of notice and compensability to the circuit court.Â  In
  closing arguments at the circuit court hearing, Magahaâ€™s counsel argued:

  I think
    notice is everything.Â  If she gave notice that she started an investigation to
    see if it was work related.Â  Clearly the hearing commissioner was also
    concerned because . . . he asked the supervisor whether the [new loom] was
    bigger than the one she used to work on and he said it was, he admitted it was
    by probably an inch or two.Â  So, that crucial two inches is very important and
    it is going down to whether she had to stretch further.Â  And I think it is not
    appropriate and it is not fair and . . . [it] is not supported by substantial
    evidence.Â  They didnâ€™t even conduct any kind of investigation, it is not legal,
    it is not proper for them to take Dr. Bryantâ€™s notes and put [them] in a
    personnel file without going out on the floor.Â  [Magahaâ€™s supervisor] couldnâ€™t
    remember anything and that was one of the biggest problems in the case. . . .
    And if a proper investigation had been done, looking at the whole record then
    they would of (sic) found the case was compensable. 

The discussion portion of the
  circuit courtâ€™s order states:Â  

  In this case, Dr. Bryant provided all the information
    that the Employer needed to properly investigate [Magahaâ€™s] injury.Â  He told
    [the Mill] that a job change had caused the impingement syndrome, that Claimant
    was experiencing pain and discomfort in her right upper extremity which was her
    predominant arm for work, and that he was requesting that the Employer cover
    the expense of medical treatment.
  This information should have launched an investigation
    by the Employer into the specifics of Claimantâ€™s medical problems and whether
    or not a work related injury had occurred.Â  Unfortunately for Claimant, the
    record does not contain any evidence that the Employer made any reasonable
    effort to determine the cause of the injury or to question the Claimant or
    plant personnel when their memories were still fresh.Â  Under these
    circumstances, the Employer would be unable to properly determine whether or
    not Claimantâ€™s medical problems were work-related.
  As a further result, the Claimant was not afforded the
    opportunity to be provided medical care and treatment by the Employer.Â  If
      this injury is later conclusively deemed work related on remand, the
    Employer has lost the chance to supervise and to direct her medical care and
    treatment. (Emphasis added.)

The order concludes:

  The only evidence in the record is that Claimant has
    met the statutory notice requirements of Section 42-15-20 as a matter of law.Â 
    The decision of the Commission is hereby reversed and the matter is remanded to
    the Commission for further findings of fact consistent with this order.

The Mill
  appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe Full
  Commission is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases.â€Â  Etheredge
    v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 454, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002).Â 
  â€œThe findings of the Commission are presumed correct and will be set aside only
  if unsupported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  However, â€œ[s]ubstantial
  evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly
  from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a
  whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the
  administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its
  action.â€Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306
  (1981).Â  A court may reverse or modify a decision of the commission if
  substantial rights of a party have been prejudiced because the findings,
  inferences, conclusions, or decisions are affected by other error of law.Â  Etheredge,
  349 S.C. at 456, 562 S.E.2d at 682.
LAW/ANALYSIS

APPEALABILITY
Our
  initial consideration in this case centers on whether the circuit courtâ€™s order
  is immediately appealable.Â  The Mill argues the circuit court reversed the
  commissionâ€™s finding on the issue of timely notice but failed to rule on the
  issue of compensability of the injury and therefore the order is final and
  immediately appealable.Â  Magaha argues the circuit courtâ€™s order remands the
  action for further proceedings and therefore the issue is not immediately
  appealable pursuant to Montjoy v. Asten-Hill Dryer Fabrics, 316 S.C. 52,
  446 S.E.2d 618 (1994).
The South Carolina appellate courts â€œhave consistently held that an order of the circuit court
  remanding a case for additional proceedings before an administrative agency is
  not directly appealable.â€Â  Montjoy, 316 S.C. at 52, 446 S.E.2d at 618.Â 
  However, our appellate courts also recognize that remand orders from the
  circuit court to an administrative agency may be immediately appealable where
  the circuit courtâ€™s order constitutes a final decision on the merits and the
  remand order has no effect on the finality of the decision.Â  Foggie v.
    General Elec. Co., 376 S.C. 384, 389, 656 S.E.2d 395, 397 (Ct. App. 2008).Â 
  In Brown v. Greenwood Mills, Inc., this court found the circuit courtâ€™s
  order finally determined an issue on the merits and the remand merely directed
  the commission to make the necessary findings to effectuate the circuit courtâ€™s
  order.Â  366 S.C. 379, 387, 622 S.E.2d 546, 551 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Viewing the
  order based on the Millsâ€™ interpretation, solely for the issue of appealability,
  we find the order immediately appealable.
NOTICE
The
  Mill first argues the circuit court erred in reversing the commissionâ€™s finding
  that Magaha gave timely notice of the accident.Â  We disagree.
Section
  42-15-20 of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act requires that every injured employee
  give the employer notice of a job-related accident within ninety days after its
  occurrence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œSection 42-15-20
  provides no specific method of giving notice, the object being that the
  employer be actually put on notice of the injury so he can investigate it
  immediately after its occurrence and can furnish medical care for the employee
  in order to minimize the disability and his own liability.â€Â  Bass v. Isochem,
  365 S.C. 454, 472-73, 617 S.E.2d 369, 379 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The notice
  requirement is to be construed liberally in favor of claimants.Â  Etheredge,
  349 S.C. at 458, 562 S.E.2d at 683.Â  
The
  Mill conceded it received Dr. Bryantâ€™s letter, in which he informs the Mill of
  Magahaâ€™s injury and its relationship to her work.Â  In Etheredge, this
  court found a letter from the employeeâ€™s family physician provided notice to
  employer.Â  Id. at 458, 562 S.E.2d at 683.Â  In light of the law requiring
  the liberal construction of the notice provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Act, we conclude Dr. Bryantâ€™s letter provided notice to the Mill.Â  Â 
COMPENSABILITY OF INJURY
The
  Mill next argues the circuit courtâ€™s remand does not affect the commissionâ€™s
  ruling on the compensability of Magahaâ€™s injury, and thus the issue of
  compensability is â€œlaw of the case.â€Â  We disagree.
â€œLaw
  of the caseâ€ is a doctrine dissuading courts from revisiting settled issues.Â 
  John R. Knight, The Law of the Case Doctrine:Â  What Does it Really Mean?,
  43-Oct. Fed.R.Law. 8 (1996).Â  Where a litigant fails to appeal a ruling on a
  particular issue, that ruling becomes law of the case.Â  See Resolution
    Trust Corp. v. Eagle Lake & Golf Condominiums, 310 S.C. 473, 475, 427
  S.E.2d 646, 648 (1993) (finding an unappealed ruling is law of the case).
After
  a thorough review of Magahaâ€™s notice of appeal to the circuit court, the
  transcript of the hearing, and the circuit courtâ€™s order, we find the doctrine
  of â€œlaw of the caseâ€ does not apply.Â  First, Magaha raised the issue of compensability
  in her notice of appeal to the circuit court.Â  Furthermore, reading the circuit
  courtâ€™s order as a whole, we find the emphasized language in the order
  indicates the circuit court expects the commission to revisit the issue of
  whether Magaha suffered an injury by accident arising out of and in the course
  and scope of her employment.Â  We recognize the circuit court did not
  specifically rule on the issue in the conclusion portion of the order.Â 
  However, given the circuit courtâ€™s clear reversal on the issue of notice, there
  was no need for the court to remand with instructions for â€œfurther findings of
  fact consistent with this orderâ€ unless the court expected further proceedings
  on the issue of injury by accident.Â  
CONCLUSION
The
  circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the commissionâ€™s finding on notice and remanding
  the action to the commission for further proceedings on the issue of whether
  Magaha suffered an injury by accident arising out of and in the course and
  scope of her employment is Â 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.Â Â  Â 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
