THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Marion H. Wolf, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert L. Wolf, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Calhoun County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-245
Heard March 7, 2008 â€“ Filed April 25, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephen R. Fitzer, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        John G. Felder and Thomas Derrick Felder, both of St. Matthews,
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The
  family court granted Marion H. Wolf (Wife) and Robert L. Wolf (Husband) a
  divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s separation and divided the partiesâ€™
  property.Â  Husband appeals, asserting the family court erred in awarding the
  marital home to Wife, in finding he was in possession of some of Wifeâ€™s
  jewelry, in awarding Wife an additional $50,000 from an investment account, and
  by admitting evidence of Husbandâ€™s conviction for tax evasion.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Wife married Husband, a physician, in New York City on November
  21, 1985.Â  Wife was then 42, Husband was 57.Â  It was the second marriage for
  both parties and no children were born of the marriage.Â  At the urging of
  Husband, the parties executed a prenuptial agreement on September 13, 1985.Â 
  The primary relevance of the prenuptial agreement to this litigation was the
  partiesâ€™ intent to treat as separate, nonmarital property all property titled in
  their respective individual names.Â  This contractual arrangement stemmed from
  Husbandâ€™s prior difficulties with the Internal Revenue Service.
Husband and Wife originally lived in New York City, where Husband
  maintained his medical practice, and in a home in Danbury, Connecticut (the
  â€œConnecticut Propertyâ€).Â  Husband acquired the Connecticut Property before the
  partiesâ€™ marriage, but Husband transferred title to his son to keep it out of
  his name for tax and other purposes.Â  The son deeded the Connecticut Property
  to Wife in 1987 for $1.00.Â  Â Â 
The couple moved to South Carolina in 1994 and acquired a horse
  farm (the Farm) known as â€œBrigadoonâ€ in St. Matthews.Â  The Farm was purchased
  in Wifeâ€™s name only for the stated price of $240,000.Â  The parties separated in
  October 2002.Â  
By
  order filed April 10, 2006, the family court granted the parties a divorce on
  the ground of one yearâ€™s separation.Â  At trial, only Wife challenged the
  validity of the prenuptial agreement.Â  The court found the prenuptial agreement
  â€œis valid under New York and South Carolina law.â€Â  The court granted Wife the
  Farm (including livestock), finding it was her separate property under the
  terms of the prenuptial agreement, as well as certain personal property.Â 
  Husband was also awarded personal property.Â  Husband was ordered to return
  certain jewelry to Wife.Â  To ensure Husbandâ€™s return of the jewelry, Wife was
  authorized to withhold $50,000 from Husbandâ€™s share of an investment account
  with Brown & Company Securities Corporation (the Brown account).Â  The
  account had a balance of just over one million dollars.Â  Husband and Wife were
  ordered to equally divide the balance of the Brown account after an initial
  $50,000 distribution was made to Wife. Â Wifeâ€™s claim for alimony was
  denied, and each party was ordered to pay his or her own attorneyâ€™s fees.Â 
  Husband appeals.[1]
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The FarmÂ 
  [Husbandâ€™s Issues I, II, IV & VI]
Husband
  argues the family court erred in awarding the Farm to Wife.Â  Specifically,
  Husband asserts the family court erred in awarding the Farm to Wife based on
  its finding Wife purchased the Farm in her name with proceeds from the sale the
  Connecticut Property, which had been gifted to her.Â  Husband states Wife had no
  tangible assets in her name when they married and the court erred by not
  considering an equitable division of the Farm and livestock because marital
  property, regardless of how title is held, is subject to equitable division.Â 
  Husband also asserts the family court erred as a matter of law in failing to
  find the marital estate was to be divided in accordance with the prenuptial
  agreement.Â  
Husband
  argues in the alternative that the family court erred in failing to find the
  Farm was transmuted into marital property because it was utilized by the parties
  in support of the marriage.Â  Husband states his income was used to maintain
  Wife and that Wife â€œnever exercised any independence to demonstrate that she
  intended the marital residence to be non-marital property.â€Â  
Husbandâ€™s
  arguments are foreclosed by the prenuptial agreement, which he did not
  challenge at trial. 
Article
  II of the partiesâ€™ prenuptial agreement, entitled â€œSeparate and Marital
  Property,â€ provides in section three as follows:

  3.Â  Each of the parties agrees that the property
    described hereafter shall remain the separate property of the other party:
  (a) all property, whether real or personal, belonging
    to or owned by the other party at the time of their marriage, including assets
    acquired by each of them in their separate names while living together outside
    the marital relationship;
  (b)Â  all property acquired by the other party out of
    the proceeds or income from property owned at the time of the marriage, or
    attributable to appreciation in value of said property, whether the enhancement
    is due to market or economic conditions or to the contributions, services,
    skill or efforts of either of the parties to this agreement;
  (c)Â  all property hereafter acquired by the other
    party by gift, devise, bequest or inheritance.Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  

 In
  awarding the Farm to Wife, the family court reasoned the Connecticut Property
  was a gift to her and that the proceeds from the sale of the Connecticut
  Property were used to purchase the Farm in her name only; therefore, the Farm
  remained Wifeâ€™s sole property in accordance with the terms of the prenuptial
  agreement.Â  Â Â 
We
  believe the prenuptial agreement controls the disposition of the Farm.Â 
  However, our analysis of the agreement focuses on a different provision than
  the one relied upon by the family court.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR
  (allowing an appellate court to affirm on any ground appearing in the record).Â 
  Article II, section four of the agreement specifically provides as follows:

  4.Â  With respect to any â€œmarital propertyâ€
    that may be acquired or accumulated during the marriage, the parties do hereby
    mutually waive, release and forego any and all rights and claims of every kind,
    nature and description, in and to the property or assets real or personal, of
      or in the name of the other, regardless of its nature, or wheresoever
    situated, and each party shall during his or her lifetime keep and retain sole
    ownership, control and enjoyment of all such property, real or personal, now
    owned or hereafter acquired by him or her, free and clear of any claim by the
    other.Â  This provision is intended to and shall serve as a complete and
    absolute waiver and release by each party to the other of any and all claims
    they may now or hereafter have with respect to the property, real and personal,
    now or hereafter owned by the other.Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  

This
  section provides that property â€œacquired or accumulatedâ€ by either party after
  the marriage will remain that partyâ€™s separate property.Â  Furthermore, the
  parties waive any right to property â€œof or in the name of the other.â€Â  Although
  the reasons for Wife having title to the Farm may be disputed, there is no
  question that it is titled solely in her name.Â  Consequently, the application
  of this provision results in Husband waiving any claim to the property and Wife
  retaining it as her own.
This is
  an unusual provision as it premises the award of property acquired after the
  marriage on title as opposed to any contribution to its acquisition, whether
  financial or otherwise.Â  However, our courts have supported the right of the
  parties to define their property rights by contractual agreement:Â  â€œ[P]arties
  are free to contractually alter the obligations which would otherwise attach to
  marriage.â€Â  Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 387, 585 S.E.2d 501, 503
  (2003).Â  
In Hardee, our supreme court cited with approval the
  following test adopted by this court to be used when determining whether a
  prenuptial agreement should be enforced:Â  â€œ(1) Was the agreement obtained
  through fraud, duress, or mistake, or through misrepresentation or
  nondisclosure of material facts?Â  (2) Is the agreement unconscionable?Â  (3)
  Have the facts and circumstances changed since the agreement was executed, so
  as to make its enforcement unfair and unreasonable?â€Â  Id. at 389, 585
  S.E.2d at 504.Â  
In the
  current appeal, the question of enforceability is not before us.Â  Wife
  questioned the enforceability of the agreement in the family court, but she
  does not appeal the family courtâ€™s finding that the prenuptial agreement is
  valid.Â  Husband has argued only that the family court misinterpreted the
  agreement or did not apply it, but he does not argue that the agreement is
  unenforceable.Â  Consequently, the family courtâ€™s finding that the agreement is
  valid is the law of the case.Â  See, e.g., Dreher v. Dreher, 370
  S.C. 75, 634 S.E.2d 646 (2006) (stating a ruling that is unappealed becomes the
  law of the case and will not be considered further on appeal).
The
  prenuptial agreement was no doubt intended to protect Husband since he had the
  vast majority of assets coming into the marriage.Â  Nevertheless, the parties
  were aware of the terms of the agreement and made the decision to title the
  Farm solely in Wifeâ€™s name.Â  The award of the Farm to Wife as her separate,
  nonmarital property may not appear equitable, but it is the result called for
  under the prenuptial agreement orchestrated by Husband.Â  As noted, the validity
  of the prenuptial agreement is the law of the case.Â  Thus, in light of the
  plain language of the agreement, we affirm the family courtâ€™s ruling that the
  Farm is the property of Wife.[2]Â  
II.Â  JewelryÂ 
  [Husbandâ€™s Issue III]
Husband
  next contends the family court abused its discretion in finding he was in
  possession of some of Wifeâ€™s jewelry.Â  
There
  is evidence in the record, as outlined by the family court, that Husband had
  access to a locked cabinet where some of Wifeâ€™s jewelry was kept along with her
  United States and British passports.Â  When Wife checked the cabinet to
  retrieve her items, everything was missing.Â  Wifeâ€™s U.S. passport later turned up
  in Husbandâ€™s possession, and he returned it to Wifeâ€™s attorney so she could
  attend her fatherâ€™s funeral.Â  Husband denied that he had removed Wifeâ€™s
  jewelry.Â  The family court found, however, that Husband removed this jewelry
  from the cabinet since he had removed Wifeâ€™s U.S. passport, which was kept in
  the cabinet with the jewelry.Â  
We hold the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s finding.Â 
  Although Husband correctly asserts there was no police report made of a theft,
  we do not think this fact is determinative.Â  If Wife believed the jewelry was
  simply retained by Husband, as opposed to stolen by an unknown third party, she
  might have reasonably believed the issue could be resolved in the divorce
  proceedings.Â  In this case, the family court judge saw and heard the witnesses
  and was in a better position to evaluate their demeanor and to assign weight to
  their credibility.Â  See Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76,
  82, 650 S.E.2d 465, 469 (2007) (â€œ[A]ppellate courts should be mindful that the
  family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, sits in a better position to
  evaluate credibility and assign comparative weight to the testimony.â€).Â  We
  find no error in the family courtâ€™s determination in this regard.
III.Â  The
  Brown AccountÂ  [Husbandâ€™s Issue V]
Husband
  contends the family court erred in awarding Wife a $50,000 distribution from
  the Brown account.Â  
In the motion to alter or amend that Husband submitted to the
  family court, he challenged the $50,000 distribution on the following basis:

  8.Â  Defendant moves [the family court] to reconsider its finding
    that the defendant should be charged with the $50,000 disbursement from the
    Brown account, since this disbursement was authorized by the court as a
    necessary and proper expenditure for defendantâ€™s needs pendente lite.Â  

On
  appeal, however, Husband asserts we should reverse the $50,000 award because it
  was not provided for in the courtâ€™s memorandum of instructions for preparing
  the order.Â  As Husband argues for the first time on appeal, the $50,000 award was
  â€œgratuitouslyâ€ placed in the order by Wifeâ€™s counsel, who drafted the order.Â 
  Although we cannot find this provision in the family courtâ€™s instructions, we
  conclude this issue is not properly before us for review.Â  Husband did not make
  the argument in the trial court that he now urges on appeal, and a party cannot
  assert error based on one ground at trial and a different ground on appeal.Â  See,
    e.g., McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley
      & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 344, 479
  S.E.2d 67, 75 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating the same ground for an objection
  must be argued to the trial court and on appeal to preserve an alleged error
  for review, and a challenge on a specific ground may not be raised for the
  first time on appeal).
IV.Â  Evidence
  of Prior ConvictionÂ  [Husbandâ€™s Issue VII]
Husband
  lastly contends the family court erred in allowing Wifeâ€™s attorney to question
  him about his conviction for tax evasion.Â  He asserts the evidence was
  inadmissible under Rule 609, SCRE because more than ten years had elapsed since
  the date of his conviction.Â  
Rule
  609(a)(2), SCRE provides that for the purpose of attacking the credibility of a
  witness, â€œevidence that any witness has been convicted of a crime shall be
  admitted if it involved dishonesty or false statement, regardless of the punishment.â€Â 
  Under Rule 609(b), SCRE, if a period of more than ten years has elapsed since
  the date of the conviction or of the release of the witness from confinement,
  whichever is later, evidence of the conviction may not be used â€œunless the
  court determines, in the interests of justice, that the probative value of the
  conviction supported by specific facts and circumstances substantially
  outweighs its prejudicial effect.â€Â  Rule 609(b) further requires that advance
  written notice of the intent to use such evidence be given to the other party.Â  Id.
During
  Wifeâ€™s direct examination, she testified that she did not know at the time she
  married Husband that he had a prior conviction for tax evasion.Â  She stated she
  did not find out about it until â€œyears later.â€Â  Husbandâ€™s counsel objected,
  arguing they were â€œgoing to try to introduce [evidence] about a conviction that
  is more than [ten] years oldâ€ and â€œ[u]nder [Rule] 609, they canâ€™t do that.â€Â 
  Wifeâ€™s counsel stated the information was offered to show that Husband did not
  disclose the information to Wife.Â  The family court overruled the objection
  without comment and no further argument was made by either party.Â  Â Â 
During Husbandâ€™s direct testimony, Husband asserted that he had
  transferred some property out of his name due in part to â€œincome tax
  problems.â€Â  On cross-examination, Wifeâ€™s counsel asked him about the nature of
  the tax difficulties.Â  Husbandâ€™s counsel did not object to this line of
  questioning, and Husband answered, â€œThe difficulty was the assertion that I
  didnâ€™t pay all my taxes.Â  The outcome was that I was convicted of that.â€Â 
  Husband stated he paid a fine and served a sentence of three months in prison.Â  Â Â 
On
  appeal, Husband summarily contends evidence of his prior conviction was
  admitted in violation of Rule 609 because more than ten years had elapsed since
  the conviction.Â  Convictions more than ten years old may be admitted after the
  court performs a balancing test.Â  Here, the family court did not perform a
  balancing test.Â  No argument was made at trial regarding the prejudicial nature
  of the conviction versus its probative effect.Â  In addition, this passing
  reference was harmless as Husband has demonstrated no prejudice.Â  First, the
  evidence was cumulative, as it came in without objection on another occasion
  via Husbandâ€™s own testimony.Â  Second, the family court noted in its memorandum
  for preparing the order that neither Wife nor Husband were credible witnesses
  and that Husbandâ€™s testimony was â€œoften evasive and misleading.â€Â  Thus, there
  were other inconsistencies in the testimony that caused the family court to
  have concerns about Husbandâ€™s credibility that were unrelated to his tax
  problems.Â  We have carefully reviewed the record, and we find ample support
  (beyond Husbandâ€™s stale conviction for tax evasion) for the family courtâ€™s
  finding that Husbandâ€™s testimony lacked credibility.
Accordingly, we find Husband has not established reversible
  error.Â  See, e.g., Jamison
    v. Ford Motor Co., 373 S.C. 248,
  261, 644 S.E.2d 755, 761 (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œTo warrant reversal based on
  the admission or exclusion of evidence, the complaining party must prove both the
  error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice.â€).
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we conclude (1) the Farm is the property of Wife pursuant to
  the terms of the partiesâ€™ prenuptial agreement; (2) evidence in the record
  supports the family courtâ€™s ruling that Husband retained possession of some of
  Wifeâ€™s jewelry; (3) the issue concerning the $50,000 distribution from the
  Brown account is not preserved for our review; and (4) Husband has shown no
  reversible error in the admission of testimony concerning his prior conviction
  for tax evasion.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  Husbandâ€™s appellate counsel did not represent Husband
  at trial.
[2]Â  Because of our disposition of this issue, we
  need not address the other arguments Husband raises regarding the Farm.Â  We
  note, however, that Husbandâ€™s argument regarding transmutation is not preserved
  for appeal as it was raised for the first time, and then only summarily, in
  Husbandâ€™s return to Wifeâ€™s reply to his motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        James Whitney
          Powell, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Carol Ann
          Hemelt, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Brian M. Gibbons, Family Court Judge
Â Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge
Â Henry T. Woods, Family Court Judge
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-246
  Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April 28,
  2008

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
REMANDED


  
    
      
        Carol Ann Hemelt, of Tega Cay, pro se.
        Michael Benjamin Smith and Thomas F. McDow, both of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this domestic action, Carol Ann Hemelt (Mother) appeals various family court
  orders finding her in contempt and changing custody.Â  We affirm in part,
  reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTS
James W. Powell
  (Father) and Mother were married on February 7, 1992.Â  One son (Child) was born
  of this marriage.Â  Mother and Father separated on April 16, 1994, and in
  October 1994, Father moved to Houston, Texas, for employment.Â  The couple was
  divorced pursuant to a 1995 North Carolina order.Â  When the marital litigation
  commenced, Child was one year old.Â  Child is now fourteen.
Father
  moved to Texas while the divorce action was pending and traveled to Charlotte by airplane every other weekend to spend three days with Child.Â  In the original
  child custody order, both Mother and Father were found to be fit and proper
  parents, and the court granted primary custody to Mother with liberal
  visitation to Father.Â  Shortly after the issuance of the divorce decree, Mother
  and Child moved to Tega Cay, South Carolina.
In 2003, Father moved
  before the North Carolina court for modification of the original custody order,
  requesting Child be allowed to fly unaccompanied for weekend and holiday
  visitations.Â  Mother, not present at the modification hearing, previously expressed
  opposition for airplane travel other than for holiday and summer visitation.Â  On
  May 21, 2003, the North Carolina court granted Fatherâ€™s motion for modification
  of visitation on the ground that Child was attending school and the prior
  visitation schedule was no longer feasible.Â  Furthermore, the North Carolina
  court found Child was able to fly unaccompanied for visitation.Â  
On March 11, 2004, Father filed a complaint in South Carolina seeking visitation in accordance with the North Carolina modification order.Â 
  In the alternative, Father sought custody.Â  On May 21, 2004, the family court
  issued a temporary order finding it was in Childâ€™s best interest for Father to
  receive visitation according to the North Carolina order.
In
  November 2005, the family court, pursuant to contempt proceedings filed by
  Father, issued a temporary/contempt order finding Mother in contempt of the
  previous order because of her willful failure to comply with the visitation
  schedule.Â  The parties eventually reached an agreement, which the family court
  approved by order dated September 22, 2006.
On
  October 6, 2006, Mother moved to vacate the order approving the partiesâ€™
  agreement, claiming she was under duress at the hearing.Â  On March 9, 2007,
  however, the family court issued a rule to show cause against Mother pursuant
  to a motion by Father and a verified complaint on his behalf seeking
  enforcement of the September 22, 2006 order and other relief.
A
  hearing on Motherâ€™s motion to vacate the September 22, 2006 order took place on
  March 12, 2007.Â  Neither party appeared; however, their respective attorneys
  and the guardian ad litem were present.Â  By order dated May 17, 2007, and filed
  May 23, 2007, the family court dismissed the motion and denied Motherâ€™s request
  for a new trial.Â  Pursuant to Rule 11, SCRCP, the family court also sanctioned
  Mother and assessed fees and costs against her.
On
  May 17, 2007, the family court held a hearing on the rule to show cause.Â 
  Although Mother was served with the rule and other pertinent documents and
  filed a responsive pleading, she did not appear at the hearing.Â  The day
  following the hearing, the family court issued an order in which it found
  Mother in contempt and ordered her to be confined for a period of one year,
  subject to provisions under which she could purge herself of contempt.Â 
  Furthermore, although Father did not seek custody in his rule to show
  cause, the family court, pursuant to its emergency protective custody powers,
  ordered the Department of Social Services to take Child into emergency
  protective custody and directed that Child be placed with Father following an
  expedited home study of Fatherâ€™s home.Â  The family court further ordered that
  â€œonce [Mother] is arrested pursuant to this order, . . . [Father] shall be
  granted custody of [Child] regardless of the status of the home study.â€Â  Mother
  subsequently filed unsuccessful motions to stay, vacate, and reconsider this
  order.Â  This appeal followed.[2]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, the appellate court
  has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624
  S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006). Â â€œThis broad scope of review, however, does not require
  the appellate court to disregard the findings of the family court.â€Â  Wooten
    v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  Moreover, â€œ[o]ur broad scope of review does not relieve the appealing
  party of the burden of showing the family court committed error.â€Â  Latimer
    v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 380, 602 S.E.2d 32, 34 (2004).Â  The family court abuses its discretion when factual findings
  are without evidentiary support or a ruling is based upon an error of law. Â Smith
    v. Doe, 366 S.C. 469, 474, 623 S.E.2d 370, 372 (2005).Â  Custody decisions
  are left largely to the discretion of the family court.Â  Kisling v. Allison,
  343 S.C. 674, 679, 541 S.E.2d 273, 276 (Ct. App. 2001). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Jurisdiction
Mother
  argues the family court erred in enforcing the modification of visitation by
  the North Carolina court. Â We disagree. Â The South Carolina family court
  modified the original order, as both parties concede it had jurisdiction to do,
  rather than enforce the North Carolina order.
A South Carolina family court of this State has jurisdiction to make a child custody
  determination by initial or modification decree if South Carolina is the home state of the child at the time of
  the commencement of the proceedings.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788 (1985).Â  Furthermore,
  a South Carolina family court may modify a custody decree of another state if
  the following criteria are met:

  (1) it
    appears to the court of this state that the court which rendered the decree
    does not now have jurisdiction under jurisdictional prerequisites substantially
    in accordance with this subarticle or has declined to assume jurisdiction to
    modify the decree and (2) the court of this state has jurisdiction.Â  

Id. Â§ 20-7-810.Â 
  Here, South Carolina meets the jurisdictional requirements for modification because
  Child lived in South Carolina when Father filed his complaint and North Carolina no longer retained continuing jurisdiction. Â 
We
  need not address whether North Carolina had jurisdiction to modify the original
  visitation order because South Carolina had jurisdiction in 2004 to make a
  modification.Â  Although the South Carolina orders refer to the North Carolina order, Fatherâ€™s complaint filed in South Carolina sought only modification
  of visitation, not enforcement of the prior North Carolina order.Â 
  Subsequently, in modifying the visitation schedule, the South Carolina family
  court chose to use the same visitation schedule as set forth in the North Carolina order.Â  Furthermore, the South Carolina family court made its own finding that
  â€œthe visitation schedule is reasonable and in the minorâ€™s child best
  interests.â€
II.Â  Service by Certified Mail
Mother
  argues the family court erred in permitting Father to serve an amended
  complaint and rule to show cause by certified mail.[3]Â 
  We disagree.Â  
After the Father
  served his complaint, Mother filed a motion seeking a more definite statement.Â 
  At the hearing on this motion, which the family court ultimately granted,
  Mother agreed to accept service of the amended complaint and rule to show cause
  by certified mail.Â  The order granting Motherâ€™s motion reflects such an
  agreement.Â  On appeal, Mother now argues service was improper under Rule 4,
  SCRCP.Â  Because, however, Mother consented to service by certified mail, such
  service was valid and cannot be attacked on appeal.Â  See Johnson v. Johnson,
  310 S.C. 44, 46-47, 425 S.E.2d 46, 48 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œOrdinarily, where a
  judgment or order is entered by consent, it is binding and conclusive and
  cannot be attacked by the parties either by direct appeal or in a collateral
  proceeding.â€). 
III.Â  Notice
Mother contends the
  family court abused its discretion in denying her motion to set aside the November
  2005 temporary/contempt order because no evidence to supports a finding that she
  received notice of Fatherâ€™s amended complaint and rule to show cause.Â  We
  disagree.
A party seeking to
  set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, has the burden of
  presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief. Lanier v. Lanier,
  364 S.C. 211, 215, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. denied,
  Sept. 20, 2006.Â  â€œThe decision to grant or deny a motion
  under Rule 60(b) is within the sound discretion of the trial court.â€ Â Bowman
    v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 151, 591 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2004); see
      also Saro Invs. v. Ocean Holiday Pâ€™ship., 314 S.C. 116, 124, 441
  S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. App. 1994) (noting that Rule 60(b) motions are addressed
  to the discretion of the court and appellate review is limited to determining
  whether the trial court abused its discretion).Â  Review is thus limited to determining
  whether the family court abused its discretion in granting or denying the
  motion.Â  Id.Â  
The record shows Mother
  consented to receiving the amended complaint and rule to show cause by
  certified mail.Â  In denying Motherâ€™s motion to set aside the November 3, 2005
  order, the family court stated, â€œ[Mother] also admitted that she would have not
  complied with the temporary order/order for contempt issues by the [family
  court] on November 3, 2005, had she been present at the hearing and the court
  rules similarly because she believed the order of May 21, 2004, to be an
  illegal one.â€Â  The family court also found the pleadings were properly sent by
  certified mail, but Mother did not claim them.[4]Â 
  Because the family court saw and heard Mother and was in a better position to
  evaluate whether her explanation that she never received the pleadings was
  credible, we hold it did not abuse its discretion in denying Motherâ€™s motion to
  set aside the November 3, 2005 order.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

IV.Â  Rule 205, SCACR
Mother maintains
  the family court violated Rule 205, SCACR, by entering a final order on
  September 22, 2006.Â  Specifically, Mother maintains the order was void because her
  first notice of appeal to this Court divested the family court of jurisdiction
  to enter further orders.Â  Mother also contends the family court erred in
  denying her motion to set aside the order because the family court had been
  divested of jurisdiction, thus rendering the order void.Â  We disagree.
Generally, the
  service of a notice of appeal automatically stay matters affected by the appeal
  and the stay continues in effect for the duration of the appeal.Â  Rule 225(a),
  SCACR.Â  Family court orders involving a child, however, are not automatically stayed.Â 
  Rule 225, SCACR(b)(6); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-2220 (1985 and Supp. 2007).Â  Because
  the September 22, 2006 order involved a child, the family court retained
  jurisdiction to enter it.Â  
V.Â  Changed Circumstances
Mother alleges
  there was no evidence of changed circumstances to warrant the order of September
  22, 2006 modifying child custody.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn
  the absence of a change of circumstances affecting the welfare of a child, a
  final decree of divorce awarding custody in accordance with an agreement of the
  parties is conclusive between them.â€Â  Pitt v. Olds, 333 S.C. 478, 481,
  511 S.E.2d 60, 61 (1999).Â  â€œIn order for a court to modify an existing custody
  decree, there must be a showing of changed circumstances occurring after the
  entry of the decree.â€Â  Id.
 When Mother and
  Father divorced in 1995, Child was two years old and not attending school.Â 
  When Father first sought modification of the visitation, Child was nine years
  old and attending school.Â  As a result, many of the provisions in the original custody
  order could no longer be implemented.Â  For example, the initial visitation
  schedule permitted Father to one extended week per month, totaling nine
  straight days.Â  Such a schedule is patently unworkable for a school-aged
  child.Â  Under these circumstances, we hold the family court did not err in
  modifying the original custody decree.Â 
Â VI.Â  Motion to set aside the September 22, 2006 order
Mother contends the family court abused its discretion
  in denying her motion to set aside the September 22, 2006 order.Â  Specifically,
  Mother maintains she was under duress at the time of the final hearing when she
  and Father reached a settlement regarding Childâ€™s visitation.Â  We disagree.
â€œA
  party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, has the
  burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief.â€Â  Lanier,
  364 S.C. at 215, 612 S.E.2d at 458.Â  â€œThe decision to grant or deny a motion
  under Rule 60(b) is within the sound discretion of the trial court.â€ Id. at 215-16, 612 S.E.2d at 458.Â  â€œReview is thus limited to determining whether
  the family court abused its discretion in granting or denying the motion.â€Â  Id.Â  
Here, Mother
  maintains she was under duress at the time of the hearing because she believed
  if she did not agree to the terms in of the settlement she would be incarcerated.Â 
  According to Mother, this â€œduress contributed to and in fact forced her into
  the agreement.â€Â  During the hearing, however, Mother testified she understood
  the terms of the agreement and had not been forced, threatened, or coerced to
  enter into the agreement.Â  Accordingly, we hold the family court did not abuse
  its discretion in denying the motion to set aside the September 22, 2006
  order.Â  
VII.Â 
  Rule 11, SCRCP 
Next,
  Mother argues the family court erred in imposing sanctions pursuant to Rule 11,
  SCRCP.Â  We disagree.
â€œA
  court imposing sanctions under Rule 11 should, in its order, describe the
  conduct determined to constitute a violation of the Rule and explain the basis
  for the sanction imposed.â€Â  Runyon v. Wright, 322 S.C. 15, 19, 471
  S.E.2d 160, 162 (1996).Â  â€œThe imposition of sanctions, however, will not be
  disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion by the lower court.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion may be found if the conclusions reached are without
  reasonable factual support.â€Â  Id.
Here,
  Mother moved to set aside the final order or in the alternative for a new
  trial.Â  In her motion, Mother maintained the final order should be set aside
  because she was under duress at when she consented to its terms.Â  Because of
  these allegations, the family court found a hearing was necessary; however,
  Mother failed to appear at the hearing to testify in her defense.Â 
  Subsequently, the family court sanctioned Mother pursuant to Rule 11, SCRCP,
  stating as follows:

  [Mother]
    never intended to abide by the terms of the agreement approved in the final
    order.Â  She deliberately misled if not lied to and presented perjured testimony
    to the court at the time of the final hearing.Â  [These] actions were designed
    to thwart the ability of the court to impose an order.Â  This motion is a continuation
    of [Motherâ€™s] deliberate acts to keep the court from exercising authority over
    her and enforcing its orders . . . [Motherâ€™s] failure to appear at this hearing
    confirms that [Mother] filed this motion to thwart the courtâ€™s authority over
    her.

We agree with the family
  court that Motherâ€™s failure to appear at the hearing and provide evidence of
  the duress she alleges prompted her to agree to the terms of the September 22,
  2006 order warranted sanctions under Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  Without such evidence, it
  was reasonable for the family court to conclude that Motherâ€™s claim was
  â€œwithout good ground to support itâ€ and was â€œinterposed for delay.â€Â  Rule
  11(a), SCRCP.
VIII.Â 
  Contempt
Mother
  contends the family courtâ€™s November 3, 2005 contempt order is void for lack of
  subject matter jurisdiction because an appeal was filed with this Court. We
  disagree.
As
  we have stated earlier in this opinion, family court orders involving a child
  are not automatically stayed.Â  Rule 225, SCACR(b)(6); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-2220 (1985 and Supp. 2007).Â  Thus, the family court had jurisdiction to
  enter an order of contempt.Â  
â€œA
  determination of contempt lies within the sound discretion of the trial court.â€
  Â Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004).
  Â An appellate court should reverse a finding of contempt only when such a
  finding is without evidentiary support. Â Id. at 396, 597 S.E.2d at 189. Â â€œ[C]ontempt is an extreme measure and the power to adjudge a
  person in contempt is not to be lightly asserted.Â  State v. Bevilacqua,
  316 S.C. 122, 128, 447 S.E.2d 213, 216 (Ct. App. 1994). Â 
â€œ[C]ontempt
  results from the willful disobedience of a court order.â€ Â Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck
    Stop, Inc. v. Cloyd, 350 S.C. 596, 607, 567 S.E.2d 514, 519 (Ct. App.
  2002). Â â€œFor purposes of contempt, an act is willful
  if â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something
  the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law
  requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or
  disregard the law.â€™ â€ Bartlett v. Rachels, 375 S.C. 348,
  352, 652 S.E.2d 432, 435 (Ct. App. 2007) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874
  (1988). 
â€œThe
  language of the commands must be clear and certain rather than impliedâ€ in
  order to support a finding of contempt for violation of a court order. Â Welchel
    v. Boyter, 260 S.C. 418, 421, 196 S.E.2d 496, 498 (1973). Â â€œBefore a person
  may be held in contempt for violating a court order, the order should inform
  him in definite terms as to the duties thereby imposed upon him, and the
  mandate alleged to be violated must be clearly expressed rather than implied.â€ Â 17
  Am. Jur. 2d Contempt Â§ 157 (1990) (quoted in Am. Fed. Bank,
    FSB v. Kateman, 335 S.C. 273, 277, 516 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 1999)).
In
  the present case, the family court found Mother in contempt for failing to
  comply with the modified visitation schedule.Â  The family court stated,
  â€œ[Mother] has indicated that she had no intent to comply with the terms of the
  agreement set forth in that final order at the time she entered into the
  agreement and has no present intent to comply with the terms . . . [Motherâ€™s]
  disobedience . . . is willful, intentional, and deliberate.â€Â  The final order
  clearly set forth the terms of the modified visitation schedule. Â Accordingly,
  the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding Mother in contempt.Â  
IX.Â 
  Emergency Protective Custody
Mother maintains the family court abused its
  discretion by entering an emergency protective custody order and erred in
  denying her motion to vacate the order after the proper procedures were not
  followed.
The family court may issue an ex parte Â order
  requiring the Department of Social Services to take a child into emergency
  protective custody without the consent of parents if the family court
  determines â€œthere is probable cause to believe that by reason of abuse or
  neglect there exists an imminent and substantial danger to the childâ€™s life,
  health, or physical safety; and parents, guardians, or others exercising
  temporary or permanent control over the child are unavailable or do not consent
  to the childâ€™s removal from their custody.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610(P)
  (Supp. 2007). 
The General
  Assembly has provided strict timelines for hearings on the removal of children.
  â€œThe family court shall schedule a probable cause hearing to be held within
  seventy-two hours of the time the child was taken into emergency protective custody.â€Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-610(M) (Supp. 2007).Â  In addition, the merits hearing â€œto determine whether
  removal of custody is needed . . . must be held within thirty-five days of the
  date of receipt of the removal petition.â€ Id.Â  A continuance may be
  granted for exceptional circumstances, however, â€œthe hearing on the merits must
  be completed within sixty-five days following receipt of the removal petitionâ€
  if a continuance is granted.Â  Id.Â  Section 20-7-736 also provides that
  the family court shall â€œschedule a hearing to be held within thirty-five daysâ€
  of the date of receipt of the removal petition.Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-736(E).
Here,
  the family court found â€œ[t]here is probable cause to believe the actions of
  [Mother] constitute abuse of the child and that there exists imminent and
  substantial danger to the childâ€™s health.â€Â  Furthermore, the family court found
  if Child remained in Motherâ€™s custody, his emotional well-being would be in
  danger.Â  Accordingly, we uphold the family courtâ€™s order to have Child taken into
emergency protective custody.Â  
There is no indication in the record, however, that
  the family court complied with statutory timelines after the Department of
  Social Services took protective custody of Child.Â  Instead, the family court
  ordered an expedited home study of Fatherâ€™s home, but also granted custody to
  Father regardless of the status of the investigation.Â  Moreover, at this point
  in time, we have no information as whether the home study has even been
  performed, let alone whether such a study would support a finding that Childâ€™s
  best interests would be served by placing him with Father.Â  Although Motherâ€™s
  conduct during this litigation may have been valid reason for the family court
  to have Child placed in emergency protective custody, we are troubled by the
  courtâ€™s apparent disregard of statutorily mandated procedures and deadlines
  that follow such extraordinary measures.Â  
Because,
  however, Child has, as best we can determine, been residing with Father during
  the pendency of this appeal, this Court will not, based on the facts before us,
  disturb his current placement.Â  Nevertheless, we reverse the provision of the
  family court order granting custody of Child to Father â€œregardless of the
  status of the home studyâ€ and remand the matter to the family court for
  completion of the home study and findings of fact as to Childâ€™s best interest
  concerning custody and visitation.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON, THOMAS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â This Court consolidated Motherâ€™s three separate
  appeals and expedited her appeal because it involved child custody.Â  
[3]Â  The rule to show cause at issue here was the one
  disposed of in the November 2005 order.Â  
[4] Â Under Rule 4(d)(8), SCRCP, â€œif delivery [of
  certified mail] is refused or is returned undelivered, service shall be made as
  otherwise provided by these rules.â€Â  Nothing in the record indicates any
  attempt of an alternative method of service.Â  Because, however, the focus of
  Rule 4 is service of the initial summons and complaint, we hold the present
  controversy is governed by Rule 5, SCRCP, under which service of pleadings
  subsequent to the original summons and complaint can be accomplished by mailing
  the papers to the party to be served and, when effected in that manner, â€œis
  complete upon mailing.â€Â  Rule 5(b)(1), SCRCP.
